story:
There are many spaces and places around the city. Some we use, some we look at, and some just need a little TLC. Detroit SOUP is looking to make the Jam Handy Building (a wonderful open space in New Center that used to be a film studio, among other things) it's new home. Last year we used this enormous space for the two year anniversary and we would like to use it year round for our microgranting dinners. What would be even better is that we would like to help it become a communal use space! In the last year it has been used for art installations, theatrical performances, music performance, beer brewing, urban farming classes, meeting space, film viewing, recital space, practice space, SOUP space, basketball games, etc.

Imagine yourself either putting your idea into practice in the space or engaging an in an event there. Now imagine in the winter, in Detroit.....it’s cold in their! Simeon (he owns the space with his brother Nat) did the math, called a few contractors, and realized that heat could be installed for $6000 and add some electrical and some lights for another $4000, we could have another venue that would be offered to the community to use for low rent or an exchange of something. Wow, really, that’s it? It’s amazing to think of what kind of community impact that space could make. East Grand Blvd. has some amazing potential become a center where art and ideas are growing and happening in the city of Detroit.

Breaking it Down:
Raising $6000 gets the Jam Handy heat for the building
Raising $10,000 gets heat, light and electrical work
Raising $15,000 gets the Jam Handy heat, light, electrical work and SOUND
Raising $20,000 get the Jam Handy all of the above and the ability to pay those bills when they come and the price of using the space does not rise!


We want the space to be a together space. We would love if we raised about another $5000. We could even think about sound and getting an established PA sound system  so that we can all use it to share our ideas. I know all this sharing stuff could sound crazy but we really believe that artists need a venue to share their ideas. This one will be all ages and the community is open to using it whether through a trade, a barter, a swap, or a contribution, the large space will be open for all to use.

So who was Jam Handy and what is this space?! Well, Jam Handy the man was by all accounts quite a character. Before arriving in Detroit and establishing his legendary film studio, Handy had already been suspended from the University of Michigan for sullying the school’s reputation by publishing a colorful cartoon poking fun at a stodgy professor, and established himself as a pioneer in the field of competitive swimming by inventing two swimming techniques (still widely used today) and capturing a bronze medal in the 1904 Olympics despite standing only 5’ 2” tall. Even than more rabble rousing and swimming, Jam Handy’s true passion was visual communication and his prescient belief that it would revolutionize education by--as he stated in one of his many delightfully anachronistic quotes--”putting the hay where the horse can reach it.”


To this end, Jam Handy moved The Jam Handy Organization to Detroit in 1932, locating it on East Grand Boulevard in order to be near his biggest client, General Motors and its 80 affiliated companies. Over the subsequent decades, Jam Handy went on to produce over 25,000 instructional films on seemingly every conceivable subject, including more than 7,000 training films for the U.S. Armed Forces during World War II. If you’re curious about what these films looked like (and you should be!) check out http://archive.org/details/jam_handy. While the Jam Handy Organization has long ceased to exist and its once sprawling network of buildings lining East Grand Boulevard has mostly disappeared from the landscape, its legacy lives on. Behind the scenes and around the world, numerous technical advancements that continue to shape the contemporary film industry owe their existence to the Jam Handy Organization. And now, here in Detroit, with the ongoing revival of the JHO’s former headquarters and main film stage, another scene--and a whole different kind of Jam Handy production--is taking place.

What is this Detroit SOUP?
Detroit SOUP is a public soup dinner! Pay $5. Learn about creative projects happening in Detroit. Vote on which project to fund with the money raised from the meal that night. It has been happening since February 2010 above the Mexicantown Bakery, currently meeting in Corktown, and soon to make a permanent home. The project gets about 150-200 people at each dinner and the new space will allow for heat and better seating, something the current space does not have.

Everyone wins with your donation. There are some awesome perks in store! Relics of the buildings history, pieces of Detroit SOUP, potential to make the space yours! Anything over $25 we will use $5 towards Detroit SOUP and the November soup dinner to help make the next dreamers project come true!

story:
Our Story

My name is Karin Persan and I own a boutique in Bushwick Brooklyn that showcases handmade products from all local designers.   The shop is located in a brand new shopping mini mall called the Loom.  Some of the other small businesses here are a salon, yarn cafe, deli, vintage shop, and yoga studio.  We have been trying to get the word out to the neighborhood and NYC in general, so I have been hosting and organizing this 1st Friday event. 

Every first Friday of the month we put today a free to the public event, where we offer discounts, have local artists install their work, perform, or demonstrate their process,  serve complimentary refreshments, and let local  organizations and groups set up and spread the word for their cause.


The Impact

We need help spreading the word!  The Bushwick community is growing, but their is so much going on here that nobody knows about!


What We Need & What You Get

I need more postcards and flyers made (100 Flyers & 500 Postcards).  I would like to get some print and web ads. To start BushwickBk (a local blog) and WG News (a free local paper). And we need help supplying the refreshments (3 cases of wine 3 cases of beer and snacks).


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Come to the Nov 5th event and bring all your friends!

story:
Please Help Bring Christina Home

Please read this plea for help with an open heart then pass this plea on to any other friends or contacts you may have, but most of all please pray for the safe return of our daughter Christina. My name is Steven Venditelli and I am the proud father of 4 adopted special needs children.

My wife and I have served for many years fostering, caring, loving, and protecting the needs of special children in the custody of the state. Christina is ten years old and is the middle child of a sibling group of three little girls that we went on to adopt nine years ago.

These children began their lives under horrific conditions although it took many years of hard work and a lot of love they have turned out to be the most beautiful, loving well-mannered children that any parent could be proud to call their own.

As most people in todayâ€™s world for the first time in my life last February I fell victim to the unemployment crisis. Not only did we lose most of our material items such as home, automobile, and whatever we sold to keep our family together.

When I lost the family medical coverage my wife who also had a debilitating neurological condition began to fall into renal failure due to the high costs of her medication that we could not afford. Once again for the first time in as many years that we have been raising children we found the desperate need to reach out to a very few people in need of temporary respite for our four special needs children.

Not only struggling to care for my wifeâ€™s condition, I also was in the process of securing a new job and housing for my family. This would mean re-locating to another state. After securing a place to live we began to reunite the family back together.

At this time Christina had been staying in the State of Connecticut with a family member who made the decision not to return her back to family and back to her two biological sisters that she had been with for her whole life.

Being in the position of starting a new job, securing medical help and services for the rest of my family, and having no savings I was distraught on how to find Christina and bring her home. I made phone calls to just about every agency in the State of Connecticut and was offered no help but told that I had the right to go to the State of Connecticut and bring our daughter home.

On March 2nd, 2012 I took out a loan for $1,500 to pay for airfare to go to Connecticut, find my daughter and bring her home. When I arrived in the City of Waterbury I immediately went to the local police department with all my proper documents in hand and it was at that time I was told that the family our daughter had filed to retain custody of our daughter. I was returned home without her and told to find myself a good lawyer.

My family has been devastated by the events that have happened especially Christinaâ€™s two sisters I have consulted with multiple attorneys in the State of Connecticut. I have found one attorney who assures me that he can bring Christina home. At this time the attorney is requesting a $5,000 retainer fee to begin representing our family.

There is a court hearing scheduled for the March 19, 2012 and with my recent expense from flying to Connecticut for nothing I am already in debt $1,500. I desperately need to raise this $5,000 retainer fee or we may lose our daughter forever. We are pleading for anybodyâ€™s help and donations in raising this amount as soon as possible so we may have an attorney at this hearing to represent our rights and bring Christina home.

story:
Updated 28 January 2012!

 

Feature Perks

Perks marked with '(feature)' provide supporters with unparrelled prelaunch site access.

Features will be added in the order that these perks sell out. Users who purchase the perk have high priority feedback level and access to the features before officially launched!

*Sold out features are guaranteed, while the other are not. Tell your friends!

I’m an artist, why should I fund you?

PlexM.com wants to provide a unique opportunity for artists. We believe by providing easy access to patrons of your work the industry can flourish.

99 Designs provides a source of steady income for graphic designers. Help us provide the same services to musicians!

I’m a brand or influencer, why should I fund you?

So you have a great marketing campaign. You have highly effective videos. But do you have the auditory pleasure component? Let us provide you with a quality selection of tracks to choose from, at your budget. 

Musicians and producers are eager to have their work heard. All you need to do is select your budget and listen as submissions start coming in. 

Jingles

Post a bounty and get many submissions for that new jingle you have been putting off getting.

YouTube Videos

Link to your soundless video in your bounty and have an audio producer submit their accompanying sound.

Video Game Sounds

Quality audio can certainly add value to a video game. Let us find artists that fit your budget.

Album Tracks

Need tracks to record over for your album? Buy exclusive rights to tracks to use on your next album.

Marketing Videos

Making the mistake of creating a bland marketing video can cost your dearly. Adding audio can save you from boring your audience.

App Sounds

Most apps require a few concise sounds. We can help you find sound effects, background audio, and the artists that produce them.

Q&A

Who are the users of this service?

Everyday countless deals are made to secure distribution rights for audio. Virtually all forms of media are affected by these deals. PlexM will make these deals easier, cheaper, and more efficient for both parties. Gone will be the days of finding a firm to broker your deals. PlexM will be the go to place where the buyers save money and the sellers make more.

Business Overview

Concept

Inspired by 99 Designs, which revolutionized the graphic art space, Plex Marketplace aims to liberate the musicians’ b2b marketplace.

Problem

Businesses must fork over substantial cash to secure exclusive rights to audio. Musicians are disconnected from the b2b marketplace due to the ancient system in place.

Solution

Replace the inefficient firms with a lightweight cloud market platform. We aim to open up communication with artists and businesses.

Management Team

The management team currently consists of me, Brian Petro. My continuous work with artists of many calibers and disciplines has given me insight on the inefficiencies for musicians.

I am also a Co-founder of A&E Halo, project management system for architects and engineers.

Developer Links:

http://careers.stackoverflow.com/brianpetro

story:
Short Summary

Hi, My name is Aaron and am law abiding  citizen  I have worked hard all my life. I have no family to support me. I lost my job to outsourcing overseas by American companies. However, not only did I lose job but also my health deteriorated due to Heart, Blood pressure and Diabetes problems. Furthermore, I have a Stent inserted in my heart due to blocked artery by Elcamino  Hospital Mountain View, California. Due to health issues and being senior citizen I am retired and currently only on fixed income and can hardly can pay for my essentials. 

My Home owners falsely accused me of threatening their security guard who confronted me in swimming pool during a hot summer day in August 2011.  He told me to get out of pool while I was at the deep endl. I requested him to please allow me to swim to shallow waters but he got upset and started calling for back up. Because of my heart problem I felt dizzy, had shortness of breath but after struggling managed to get out of the pool before reaching to shallow waters. The reason he did was because he thought I was not resident but the fact is I am a home owner there and proved my residency to them. While he compelled me to get out of the pool, his accomplice, a foot taller than me, chased me with a clinched fist and calling me names. When I complained to Home Owners Association, they instead of taking action against them, slapped me with a hefty fine which I am unable to pay as I am not only on fixed income but innocent too. I have witness statement to prove that I am an innocent person.

   

What We Need & What You Get

T. Please help me to pay for my legal which could cost around$25,000/. 

The Impact

Home Owners Association  have also threatened me with putting lien on my property which gives me nightmares as I could lose my retirement home

Due to crisis in housing market even though I am home owner I lost all equity in my house

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
The Background

Ongoing economic tumult has left no one untouched, unscathed. Some, though, have been hit harder than others. I lost my primary source of income on the Friday before Thanksgiving in 2008. Since then, I've applied for jobs, pitched projects, and pursued every lead that crossed my path... all to no avail. Short-term unemployment benefits and some money from a lawsuit settlement bridged the gap for the first two years between my income as a freelance writer and my bare-bones monthly expenses. Despite a vehicle downgrade and personal austerity measures, I continue to run a small deficit each month and no work opportunities seem likely to come my way any time soon.


So, I'm taking a different tack. And I need your help.


The Notion

One of the things I'm most passionate about is being of service to others, contributing to the greater good. With your support, I can put that passion to good use working with organizations like H.A.R.P., The If Project, and the Charlotte Maxwell Complementary Clinic. With my myriad skills, I can produce web content, coordinate fund-raising, update social media, and more to give these great community service groups an extra set of helping hands.   


In order to free myself up for this volunteer work, I need to cut my overhead expenses to a level that falls beneath my current freelance writing income. That means not paying rent, because pretty much everything else that can be eliminated is long gone. To achieve this next level of living lean, I want to purchase a cheap, old, reliable motorhome to live in. That way, I can go where I can be of assistance, all the while keeping my ongoing expenses within my current means. 


The Pitch

Setting myself up with a motorhome (replete with a few eco-friendly improvements) will cost me somewhere between $5,000 and $8,000. I'm willing to chip in the very measly funds I have because I see it as an investment in my future. Might as well have my money in a tangible resource rather than a low-interest savings account, right? Besides, this is about coming together to do something bigger than any one person.


For every $20 donated to my motorhome fund, I will volunteer one hour of time to one of the following organizations (you choose!) with fund-raising as a target task. That way, not only do your dollars put a roof over my head, they also get turned into more dollars through my efforts. Me spending, say, 20 hours to produce a benefit compilation album (a $400 value) could generate $5,000 or more for the organization. Put me to work for maybe 40 hours producing a benefit concert (an $800 value) and the revenues could jump to well over $10,000 for the charity. Everybody wins in this game!


If I don't hit the $5,000 goal, I can either hold off on some of the eco refurb or finagle some other way around. (But let's hope it doesn't come to that.)


The Orgs

H.A.R.P.: H.A.R.P. (Humanitarian Aid & Rescue Project) was created by founder Burke Bryant after he recognized that the need for emergency aid was most crucial during the exact time of conflict. He also recognized that during this time, most aid organizations failed to deliver aid until after conflicts had reached a more moderate level. This is where H.A.R.P. separates itself from the rest; we enter the heart of conflict and rapidly deploy emergency aid with the goal of saving as many lives as possible. In short, H.A.R.P. delivers emergency aid to areas where others only dare to go.

The If Project: “If there was something someone could have said or done that would have changed the path that led you here, what would it have been?” Detective Kim Bogucki posed this question to a group of prisoners at the Washington Correction Center for Women. Initially, it was just posed randomly to the group and inspired some discussion. On her next visit to WCCW, Detective Bogucki was surprised to find this question had incited great inspiration with one inmate, Renata Abramson. Renata had taken it upon herself to share this question with her fellow prisoners. She asked them to take time, really consider the question, and write down what they felt. Through them, we will search for answers as to how to break the chain of felonies that have brought them all here, in the hopes of preventing others from doing the same. To date, we have collected over 240 essays.


Charlotte Maxwell Complementary Clinic: The Charlotte Maxwell Complementary Clinic (CMCC) is a landmark public health clinic that has been providing free complementary alternative medicine (CAM) treatments and comprehensive social services to low-income women with cancer since 1991. CMCC serves over 800 women in the Bay Area who are battling both cancer and poverty, supporting them in completing conventional cancer treatment. Seventy-five percent of our client base are women of color and, for over 40 percent, English is not their first language. Sixty-five percent of all CMCC clients have advanced cancers and are undergoing rigorous treatments in their quest to survive.

The Ask

If you find my aim is true, please contribute whatever you feel comfortable giving. My gratitude will make its way to you wherever you may be. And if you don't mind spreading the word around a bit, that very same gratitude will know no bounds.
story_txt:
The Background
Ongoing economic tumult has left no one untouched, unscathed. Some, though, have been hit harder than others. I lost my primary source of income on the Friday before Thanksgiving in 2008. Since then, I've applied for jobs, pitched projects, and pursued every lead that crossed my path... all to no avail. Short-term unemployment benefits and some money from a lawsuit settlement bridged the gap for the first two years between my income as a freelance writer and my bare-bones monthly expenses. Despite a vehicle downgrade and personal austerity measures, I continue to run a small deficit each month and no work opportunities seem likely to come my way any time soon.

So, I'm taking a different tack. And I need your help.

The Notion

One of the things I'm most passionate about is being of service to others, contributing to the greater good. With your support, I can put that passion to good use working with organizations like H.A.R.P., The If Project, and the Charlotte Maxwell Complementary Clinic. With my myriad skills, I can produce web content, coordinate fund-raising, update social media, and more to give these great community service groups an extra set of helping hands.   

In order to free myself up for this volunteer work, I need to cut my overhead expenses to a level that falls beneath my current freelance writing income. That means not paying rent, because pretty much everything else that can be eliminated is long gone. To achieve this next level of living lean, I want to purchase a cheap, old, reliable motorhome to live in. That way, I can go where I can be of assistance, all the while keeping my ongoing expenses within my current means. 


The Pitch
Setting myself up with a motorhome (replete with a few eco-friendly improvements) will cost me somewhere between $5,000 and $8,000. I'm willing to chip in the very measly funds I have because I see it as an investment in my future. Might as well have my money in a tangible resource rather than a low-interest savings account, right? Besides, this is about coming together to do something bigger than any one person.

For every $20 donated to my motorhome fund, I will volunteer one hour of time to one of the following organizations (you choose!) with fund-raising as a target task. That way, not only do your dollars put a roof over my head, they also get turned into more dollars through my efforts. Me spending, say, 20 hours to produce a benefit compilation album (a $400 value) could generate $5,000 or more for the organization. Put me to work for maybe 40 hours producing a benefit concert (an $800 value) and the revenues could jump to well over $10,000 for the charity. Everybody wins in this game!

If I don't hit the $5,000 goal, I can either hold off on some of the eco refurb or finagle some other way around. (But let's hope it doesn't come to that.)


The Orgs

H.A.R.P.: H.A.R.P. (Humanitarian Aid & Rescue Project) was created by founder Burke Bryant after he recognized that the need for emergency aid was most crucial during the exact time of conflict. He also recognized that during this time, most aid organizations failed to deliver aid until after conflicts had reached a more moderate level. This is where H.A.R.P. separates itself from the rest; we enter the heart of conflict and rapidly deploy emergency aid with the goal of saving as many lives as possible. In short, H.A.R.P. delivers emergency aid to areas where others only dare to go.


The If Project: “If there was something someone could have said or done that would have changed the path that led you here, what would it have been?” Detective Kim Bogucki posed this question to a group of prisoners at the Washington Correction Center for Women. Initially, it was just posed randomly to the group and inspired some discussion. On her next visit to WCCW, Detective Bogucki was surprised to find this question had incited great inspiration with one inmate, Renata Abramson. Renata had taken it upon herself to share this question with her fellow prisoners. She asked them to take time, really consider the question, and write down what they felt. Through them, we will search for answers as to how to break the chain of felonies that have brought them all here, in the hopes of preventing others from doing the same. To date, we have collected over 240 essays.


Charlotte Maxwell Complementary Clinic: The Charlotte Maxwell Complementary Clinic (CMCC) is a landmark public health clinic that has been providing free complementary alternative medicine (CAM) treatments and comprehensive social services to low-income women with cancer since 1991. CMCC serves over 800 women in the Bay Area who are battling both cancer and poverty, supporting them in completing conventional cancer treatment.  Seventy-five percent of our client base are women of color and, for over 40 percent, English is not their first language.  Sixty-five percent of all CMCC clients have advanced cancers and are undergoing rigorous treatments in their quest to survive. 
The Ask

If you find my aim is true, please contribute whatever you feel comfortable giving. My gratitude will make its way to you wherever you may be. And if you don't mind spreading the word around a bit, that very same gratitude will know no bounds.

story:
www.foodshedproductions.org

Our Story

We are a French / American couple seeking funding for materials to hold annual exhibitions of art and photography.  Professional Graphic Designer and photographer of 10 years; their exhibition features: ï¿½a year on an organic farm,ï¿½ in Paonia, Colorado.  Having honed their skills at www.thelivingfarm.org with the 2011 Sustainable Settings recipient of Organic Farmer of the Year, they are now looking for a creative and fun way to generate excitement for a social benefit corporation (B-Corp) - www.bcorporation.net/.  Their start-up called FoodShedProductions has a focus on the development of local foodsheds that bring the production-consumption cycle onto the property of a homeowner.  This organic gardening education will aid residents save money while eating organically and complementing healthy lifestyles.  From the western slope to the eastern slope, they will be bound to Boulder County, CO and its neighboring counties starting in 2012.

Nous sommes un couple franco-americain en recherche de fincancements pour monter une exposition de photographies. Marion est un designer graphique et August, un photgraphe amateur depuis 10 ans. Leur exposition retrace "un an dans une ferme biologique", a Paonia, Colorado. Apres avoir affute leurs couteaux a www.thelivingfarm.org (declaree "Ferme Biologique de l'annee 2011" par Sustainable Settings Aspen), ils entreprennent un nouveau projet d'entreprise sociale (B-Corp) - www.bcorporation.net/.

Leur start-up s'appelle FoodshedProductions et se focalise sur le developpement de sources d'alimentations locales de maniere a ramener la production de legumes chez le consommateur meme, dans son jardin. Nous mettons en place un programme pedagogique pour aider les residents qui font appel a FoodshedProductions a etre autonome dans le maintien de leur potager, en ayant une alimentation equilibree tout en faisant des economies. Notre entreprise sera localisee, a partir de 2012 dans la region de Boulder, Colorado et ses voisinages.

The Impact of an Education

In year one, FoodShedProductions will be offering a personalized education in organic gardening.  August and Marion will be working with suburban residents who desire an intimate connection with their food and how it can be organically grown.  The goal of FoodShedProductions is to educate homeowners to be self-sufficient gardeners.


Marion and August of FoodShedProductions will met potential clients to discuss the style of garden, the best sites, the corresponding type and quantity of vegetables best suited for their family and the site, and the number of gardening workshops desired.  After agreeing on a plan of action the next visit will be devoted to the construction and planting of a personal garden.  In addition each resident will receive a compost turner, a seed starter and a cold frame.  Marion or August will teach/demonstrate how each tool is effectively used and impart the knowledge needed for your garden's success.


In all, home gardens can include the construction of multiple beds, a 24a x 12a high tunnel, chicken coop and fencing, install drip line irrigation, and provide workshops on succession and companion planting, watering, pruning, bed flipping as well as canning, dehydration, and freezing.  


In year two, FoodShedEducations will join FoodShedProductions.  A community development & organizing non-profit that funds neighborhood projects by selling organic produce at local farmers markets with the food grown by neighbors from your neighborhood. FoodShedEducations aids neighborhoods in strengthening communal bonds through the pursuit of community defined & directed development projects.  This form of Neighborhood Supported Agriculture provides a needed opportunity for support networks of neighbors to establish themselves through community participation.


La premiere annee, FoodshedProductions offrira des potagers biologiques sur mesure. August et Marion travailleront avec des residents de la peripherie de Boulder qui souhaitent renouer le lien avec l'origine de leur alimentation et comprendre comment tout cela pousse sans pesticides. Le but de FoodshedProductions est de sensibiliser et apprendre aux residents a etre des jardiniers autonomes procurant legumes et herbes pour leur famille.

Un client type de FoodShedProductions viendrait nous voir et nous discuterions du type de potager desire en rapport au terrain, la quantite de legumes souhaites, et le nombre de visites (workshops, lecons) qu'il souhaite que l'on mette en place pour lui. Apres s'etre mis d'accord sur un plan d'action, notre visite suivante consiste a mettre en place le potager. Le potager est livre avec un composte, un kit pour germer les graines et une "cold frame" (sorte de boite composee de panneaux de bois et d'une fenetre pour couvercle permettant  une meilleure resistance des plantes contre le froid). Marion et August enseigneront l'usage de  ces outils pour un usage tout au long de l'annee.

Toutes options comprises, le jardin  la construction de multiples zones de plantation, une serre, un poulailler, une cloture, un systeme d'irrigation et le jardinier recevra une succession de workshops.

La deuxieme annee, FoodShedEducations joindra FoodShedProductions. Cette association se developpera autour de l'organisation de communaute dans le but de financer des projets choisi par la communaute, le voisinage. Pour ce faire, les residents auront un stand sur un marche et vendront l'exces de produits de leur jardin respectifs. FoodShedEducations vise a renforcer les liens sociaux des voisinages concernes par une participation a la vie de la communaute.

How Your Money Will Be Spent

The annual farm art exhibition will be FoodShedProductions' form of indirect advertising, contributions will allow us to purchase recycled barnwood frames, matting board, and prints. 


Beyond the exhibition, the money generated will be utilized to purchase materials for FoodShedProductions including: a small truck, roto-tiller, compost, other equipment, and tools so that we can better serve clients and community.


L'exposition de photographies sera pour nous une facon indirecte de promouvoir notre entreprise, et l'argent recolte nous aidera en partie a payer pour le materiel de l'expo.

Au dela de l'exposition, l'argent sera utilise pour acheter du materiel de jardinage pour FoodShedProductions tel que : un motoculteur electrique, du composte, des outils generaux (rateaux, pelles...), un petit pick-up....

Tell Mom, Tell Dad, Tell A Neighbor, A Relative, A Friend, Or Co-Worker

Help us get the word out.  Help us empower residents and communities: to eat the organic food they produce, to define and direct their neighborhoods development as they know best, to feel connected, and to share their knowledge with those they love.


Si le coeur vous en dit, aidez -nous a diffuser notre projet pour donner l'opportunite a des particuliers et des voisinages de manger les legumes bio qu'ils auront produit, et a partager cette experience avec ceux qu'ils cherissent.

story:
HELP UGANDA

Since 1999, HELP International has been dedicated to fighting poverty and empowering people through community development initiatives in education, public health and business in some of the poorest countries around the world.

HELP International has been serving in Uganda since 2006, and this summer HELP will send two teams to Uganda to carry out its mission of: empowering people to fight global poverty through sustainable, life-changing development programs.

Teams will serve in Mbale and Lugazi, Uganda and will be comprised of two Country Directors who will lead 20 to 30 volunteers.

In partnership with local community members and organizations, HELP will be working on sustainable development projects that include: 

  • Nutrition and income generation through vertical gardens – which provide subsistence farming for families that do not own their own land in the Namatala slum near Mbale, Uganda. HELP teams built 10 vertical gardens last year.
     
  • Empowerment through the Proud to Be a Girl Campaign – teaching the girls of Uganda women’s health, empowerment and self esteem.
     
  • Potential lives saved through Mbale Blood Drive – In 2011, HELP teams held a three-day blood drive, which recruited 230 blood donors - potentially saving 460 lives in Mbale Hospitals. HELP is hoping to grow this program in 2012.
     
  • Improving education through teacher trainings – HELP teams partnered with the Minster of Education to provide teacher training to 338 teachers and hold Mbale’s first science fair, which hosted participants from 48 schools.
     
  • Improved health care through eye and dental clinics – in 2011, 94 patients were given eye exams and 32 patients dental exams. Sixty-eight pairs of glasses were distributed, and HELP is hoping to increase these numbers this summer.
     
  • Clean drinking water through water filters and rain harvesting systems – more than 2,000 people were provided clean drinking water in 2011, and the need for water sanitation is still great throughout Uganda.
     
  • Community development through soccer club in Natamala slum - 45 youth were taught leadership skills through this club that we would like to grow in 2012.
     
  • Entrepreneurship through business trainings – participants are taught basic entrepreneurial and micro-enterprise business skills as well as income-generating activities.

However, in order to run these programs and serve the people of Uganda in 2012 – we need your HELP! 

WHY UGANDA NEEDS YOUR HELP

Uganda has gotten ample press recently; however, the problems facing the people of Uganda extend beyond Kony. Known as the “Pearl of Africa”, Uganda is rich in natural resources, yet its people remain deeply impoverished and in great need. Illiteracy is common, especially among females. The infant mortality rate is high – 82 deaths per 1,000 live births. 36% of people do not have access to clean drinking water.

The facts surrounding Uganda aren’t all dire. In the 1980’s more than 25% of Ugandans were infected with HIV; however, this rate has fallen to less than 7%. Uganda boasts the most effective national response to HIV/AIDS of any African country. HELP International is hoping to help create more success stories for the people of Uganda. 

WHERE DOES MY MONEY GO?

Your donations will go directly towards sustainable development initiatives in Uganda, and every donation will help the people of Uganda! 100% of your donation goes to improving the communities and lives of people in Lugazi and Mbale, Uganda. Any size donation, even $1, helps, and your contribution is greatly appreciated! 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Even if you aren’t able to donate, you can still help! Please share with your friends and family the work that HELP international is doing in Uganda. Please help by sharing this link on Facebook, Twitter, or via email. Thank you for your help and support! 

FOR MORE INFORMATION

Please visit the HELP website for more information, and how to get involved. To make a payment by credit card click here or to make a tax deductible donation through Help International's PayPal site click here and follow the instructions. Please remember to designate your donation to the Uganda programs.

story:
What is capoeira?

Capoeira is a game. It's music, movement, history. It's a philosophy. It's a way of life rooted in the social struggles that came with the transatlantic slave trade. 

 

Here's a timeline to put us in context:

 

1500         The brutality of transatlantic slavery begins. Free African men and women are taken by force, packed onto horrid slave ships and brought to Brazil to work on sugarcane plantations.

1808            Capoeira emerges through the cultural hybridization of enslaved men and women of the African diaspora. They are able to express their African identity through dance, music and warrior rituals.

1814            Any form of African cultural expression is prohibited by colonial oppressors.

1888            Slavery is abolished but the disenfranchised Afro-Brazilians continue to use capoeira as a form of underground resistance.

1889            Vicente Ferreira Pastinha was born and was to be known as Mestre Pastinha, the most influencial capoeira angola master to exist at the time.

1942            People rediscover the value of capoeira through its institutionalisation. Mestre Pastinhaâ€™s academy opens and brings forth two very revered diciples Mestre Joao Pequeno and Mestre Joao Grande.

1982            Mestre Moraes, student of Joao Grande opens the Capoeira Angola Pelourinho Group (GCAP) in Bahia, Brazil.

1985           Jurandir Nascimento, along with Cinezio FÃ©liciano PeÃ§nanha (Cobra Mansa), both students of Mestre Moraes become pioneers of the group.

1995            Cobra Mansa along with Jurandir  and Mestre Valmir found the International Capoeira Angola Foundation (FICA) in Washington D.C.

2012            FICA is now international in scope. Mestres Cobra Mansa, Jurandir and Valmir travel the world giving conferences, workshops and lectures year round.

Note: These dates are approximate and may vary depending on the source.

 

FICA in Montreal

Fabrice Koffy, Kseniya Smaryanakis, Celeste Nelson and Ron Scott collectively lead FICA Study Group Montreal and strive to stay connected to the source.

 

Being guided by a capoeira master is crucial to the development of our young group. Despite our regular trips to Brazil, our exposure to the art form is very limited. With only a handful of capoeira angola groups in Canada, we are 1 of 2 in the province of Quebec.

 

Weâ€™ve been giving weekly capoeira angola classes in Montreal since 2006 and became a study group of FICA just last year.


What will we do with your donation? 

It is becoming increasingly important to deepen our understanding of the martial art if we want to continue growing in our practice. We are a non-profit grass-root collective and all of our profits go back into the group to pay for space rentals, instruments and hosting workshops.

 

We need $2500 to cover the costs of Mestre Jurandirâ€™s visit. We have already a fifth of this amount and we want to raise the rest with your help.

Expenses for this event include:


Â· Airplane tickets to and from Montreal

Â· Accommodation

Â· Food

Â· Transportation

Â· Studio rentals

Â· Remuneration


Why Mestre Jurandir?

Itâ€™s not easy to make a living off capoeira angola and we want to support Mestre Jurandir financially in his mission to preserve the art form. He has dedicated over 30 years to capoeira angola and uses the practice as a tool for social change. He has done work in America with juvenile delinquents, kindergardeners, high school kids and abandoned children in the slums of Brazil. Mestre Jurandir's dedication has even brought him to MoÃ§ambique where he has been twice already to support community-building and youth empowerment through capoeira angola. Mestre Jurandir is a goldmine of knowledge and this is why want to have him in Montreal. 



What will you gain from giving?

By making a donation, you will get one of the following perks:

  1. A postcard
  2. Maple bonbons
  3. Montreal designer t-shirt
  4. Capoeira CD

 

Plus, by contributing to our cause, you become an active agent in strengthening our community and help us mobilize capoeira angola to:

  • develop a sense of community;
  • empower the youth;
  • share insight into the Afro-Brazilian culture;
  •  show how the practice benefits mind, body and spirit.

This is why bringing Mestre Jurandir to Montreal means so much.


If you believe in our work, spread the word and share this cause with friends and family! Because it

takes a community to raise consciousness about social injusticesâ€”for us, capoeira angola does just that.


To learn more about our cause, join our community on Facebook and visit our website at jogodeangola-mtl.com.



Thank you for your generosity and for helping us fly our capoeira master from Brazil

to Montreal, Canada!
story_txt:
What is capoeira?
Capoeira is a game. It's music, movement, history. It's a
philosophy. It's a way of life rooted in the social struggles that came with
the transatlantic slave trade. 

 
Here's a timeline to put us in context:

 


1500         The brutality of transatlantic slavery
begins. Free African men and women are taken by force, packed onto horrid slave ships and
brought to Brazil to work on sugarcane plantations.

1808 
          Capoeira
emerges through the cultural hybridization of enslaved men and women of
the African diaspora. They are able to express their African identity through
dance, music and warrior rituals.
1814 
          Any
form of African cultural expression is prohibited by colonial oppressors.
1888 
          Slavery
is abolished but the disenfranchised Afro-Brazilians continue to use
capoeira as a form of underground resistance.
1889 
          Vicente
Ferreira Pastinha was born and was to be known as Mestre Pastinha, the
most influencial capoeira angola master to exist at the time.
1942            People rediscover the value of capoeira through
its institutionalisation. Mestre Pastinhaâ€™s academy opens and brings forth two
very revered diciples Mestre Joao Pequeno and Mestre Joao Grande.
1982            Mestre Moraes, student of Joao Grande opens the Capoeira
Angola Pelourinho Group (GCAP) in Bahia, Brazil.
1985           Jurandir
Nascimento, along with Cinezio
FÃ©liciano PeÃ§nanha (Cobra Mansa), both students of Mestre Moraes become
pioneers of the group.
1995            Cobra Mansa along with Jurandir  and Mestre
Valmir found the International Capoeira Angola Foundation (FICA) in Washington
D.C.
2012            FICA is now
international in scope. Mestres Cobra Mansa, Jurandir and Valmir travel the
world giving conferences, workshops and lectures year round.


Note: These dates are approximate and may vary depending on the source.

 
FICA in Montreal
Fabrice Koffy, Kseniya Smaryanakis, Celeste Nelson and Ron
Scott collectively lead FICA Study Group Montreal and strive to stay connected
to the source. 

 
Being guided by a capoeira master is crucial to the
development of our young group. Despite our regular trips to Brazil, our
exposure to the art form is very limited. With only a handful of capoeira
angola groups in Canada, we are 1 of 2 in the province of Quebec.

 
Weâ€™ve been giving weekly capoeira angola classes in Montreal
since 2006 and became a study group of FICA just last year. 


What will we do with your donation? 
It is becoming increasingly important to deepen our
understanding of the martial art if we want to continue growing in our
practice. We are a non-profit grass-root collective and all of our profits go back into the
group to pay for space rentals, instruments and hosting workshops.

 
We need $2500 to cover the costs of Mestre Jurandirâ€™s visit. We have already a fifth of this amount and we want to raise the rest with your help.
Expenses for this event include:

Â· Airplane
tickets to and from Montreal 
Â· Accommodation

Â· Food
Â· Transportation
Â· Studio rentals
Â· Remuneration

Why Mestre Jurandir?
Itâ€™s not easy to make a living off capoeira angola and we want to support Mestre Jurandir financially in his mission to preserve the art form. He has dedicated over 30 years to capoeira angola and uses the practice as a tool for social change. He has done work in America with juvenile delinquents, kindergardeners, high school kids and abandoned children in the slums of Brazil. Mestre Jurandir's dedication has even brought him to MoÃ§ambique where he has been twice already to support community-building and youth empowerment through capoeira angola. Mestre Jurandir is a goldmine of knowledge and this is
why want to have him in Montreal. 


What will you gain from giving?
By making a donation, you will get one of the following perks:



A postcard


Maple bonbons


Montreal designer t-shirt


Capoeira CD




 
Plus, by contributing to our cause, you become an active agent
in strengthening our community and help us mobilize capoeira angola to:



develop a sense of community;


empower the youth;


share insight into the Afro-Brazilian culture;

 show how the practice benefits mind, body and spirit.



This is why bringing Mestre Jurandir to
Montreal means so much.

If you believe in our work, spread the word and share
this cause with friends and family! Because it
takes a community to raise consciousness about social injusticesâ€”for us, capoeira angola does just that.

To learn more about our cause, join our community on Facebook and visit our website at jogodeangola-mtl.com.


Thank you for your generosity and for helping us fly our capoeira master from Brazil
to Montreal, Canada!

story:
My name is Malin Ramirez and I am the manager of Sacred Heart Community Service's, La Mesa Verde program, an urban food sovereignty program committed to building sustainable communities through the development of a network of home-scale food producers. We work with low income families in the San Jose area.

One of our families needs your help. Debbie Meza is one of our amazing 2012 gardeners, volunteer, and community leaders. She is suffering from financial hardship. She and her husband have been looking for work for a number of months with no luck. Their landlord is evicting them at the end of the month. While Debbie has been waiting for employment she has been volunteering her time at Sacred Heart Community Service at the Joblink program and with data entry at La Mesa Verde. In addition, she has been involved in numerous community campaigns through the Policy, Advocacy, and Organizing program at Sacred Heart.

She is a tremendous resource to our community and an asset to our agency. Debbie is a generous person with a big heart. She has volunteered her family to help the community and her home for preserving/canning classes.

We need to raise enough money for the Meza family to be able to stay in their home.  We are trying to raise $4000 by the end of the month. If we don't make our goal any funding raised will be used to help the Meza's find a new home. 

For your donations:

For a $50 dollar donation, my mother will make you a unique handcrafted kitchen towel.

For $100 dollar donation, you get a handcrafted jar of curtido (pickled jalapeno and veggies)

For $500 dollar donation, you get a handcrafted garden basket filled with a kitchen towel, jar of curtido, and a jar of my mother's famous plum wine.

story:
Help the Concert for the Caring help our communities!

The Concert for the Caring is a new and exciting fundraising event, designed to bring caring people together in communities across the country.

We have a good start. We have done several concerts in support of various causes, the Haiti earthquake, CASA (Court Appointed Special Advocates), and United Way to name a few. Audiences enjoyed the events, comments trend towards “inspiring” and “moving”- exactly what we want to hear.

The concerts feature the original songs of Atlantic Records legacy artist Morgan Paul. His inspiration has been over a decade of work in the city of Paterson NJ, supporting Food Pantries, Homeless Shelters, and other charities who do the good work, helping those most in need, every day.

Morgan Paul found songwriting inspiration in the difficult lives of folks who struggle every day for just the basics, food, clothing and shelter. “It’s complex!”, says Morgan Paul. “At this basic level, just surviving is about as stressful as it gets. Lots of people do what they can to help, only to have something else get in the way. Kids get an education, then they go home to drugs, poor nutrition, and domestic violence, and there goes the education lesson.” Some would find that frustrating, difficult to raise support for, but Morgan Paul saw it differently.

To help bring attention to the need, Morgan Paul wrote over 90 compelling and moving songs, each with a story to tell. (Including “Live United” for the United Way, ”Before I Can’t Remember” for the Alzheimer’s Association, and “Where Hope Begins” for Eva’s Village.) As that developed, reviews were favorable. Folks liked the songs and loved the messages. A concert was the next step and it was then that the Haiti earthquake happened.

That concert, “People United to Save Haiti” (PUSH) brought together 400 local residents in the Paterson NJ area and they raised over $2000 in donations and sponsorships. Not bad for a first effort. What was immediately clear was that people, LOTS of people, want to help their neighbors.

As the economy tanked, the charity world began asking for more and more money, from fewer and fewer donors. That is unsustainable. Eventually, you will lose your big donors and funding will disappear in big chunks. But the regular folks don’t have a lot of money to spare in this economy, they just want to help somehow.  

Morgan Paul saw that a local concert event could raise a lot of money, in small individual amounts. Local concerts can attract 1000 or more people. He guessed most folks might afford $20 a ticket for a great night of moving entertainment. He was right. People readily pay $20 for a Concert for the Caring event. However getting the word out to attract 1000 people has been a challenge.

Morgan Paul decided to take a leap of faith. To keep the cost of The Concert for the Caring as low as possible, he invested in all of the equipment necessary to put on a show. This, so there would be no charges for sound, lights, and ultimately staging. You see the Concert for the Caring this year has been blessed with a mobile stage! Well it wasn’t always a mobile stage, it was a construction office trailer from 1965. But Morgan Paul saw it differently. With the help of his son, the old structure was removed and the deck became the stage. A new set of axles and wheels, plus several hundred hours of labor, made the dream a reality!

But now its time to get the show on the road. That’s where you come in. We are trying to raise $25,000 to get The Concert for the Caring into towns across the North East region in 2013. The money will go to fine tuning the technical side of the show, for basic expenses, and especially for getting the word out that this exciting fundraising event is ready to help raise money and awareness of the needs in every community.

So please be generous! Be a part of something big! We see this as the future of fundraising, a way to reach folks who don’t go to Golf Outings, or Gala Dinners, who just want to enjoy a great concert as they help out their communities.

 As a little ‘thanks’, we will send all donors the original Morgan Paul song,” I Have a Friend” via email. $100+ donors will get the most recent Concert for the Caring CD, 12 songs, dedicated to you or a loved one. $1000+ donors will enjoy all of the above, plus be Morgan Paul’s VIP guest at all 2013 shows. When we reach our goal of $25,000, all donors will be invited to a special Concert for the Caring, in recognition of the generosity of people who truly care and have made a difference.

Together, we can make our world a better place!

Many thanks!

Paul Bailey (a.k.a. Morgan Paul. Shhhhh... It’s a
secret!)

story:
Short Summary

We offer programs and services that encourage, dream realization, cultural awareness, personal growth, civic engagement, community investment and family unity.

Our primary objective is to lay a foundation for realizing dreams from the inside out that will instill a lifelong desire to achieve the seemingly impossible and develop young adults that participate in society as educated productive members of the community.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $3000.00 to support our youth programs and operations.

We are asking for your support so that we will be able to provide quality programs and services to the community. The staff of CTD Dream Builders is all volunteers and although we do this from our hearts we still have to pay the bills.

All heartfelt donations to support any of the programs of Challenging Their Destiny, Dream Builders are needed and will be appreciated. Your name will be added to our positive affirmation board of community members who care about the future of our youth. This board will be displayed on our web site and at all community events we participate in.

Funds will directly support our cause and further our impact in the community.

We also have a wish list of major things the organization is in need of:

We have our eye on a building in North Sacramento, that we would love to turn into the Dream Builders Youth Community Center. It is located in an area where youth don't always feel safe. Our community center would provide a safe haven for these youth.

Scholarship fund for college bound youth.

We need a van to transport youth to our events and field trips.

We need computers and Multi-media equipment for the youth programs.

Office supplies

Sponsors

Volunteers

People to spread the word about what we are doing and start building dreams in your community too.

 

The Impact

Child exploitation and human trafficking is a danger facing young girls in Northern California daily. Our programs give young women the tools they need to guide them in making the right choices in life.

One of our programs Beautiful from Inside and Out (BFIO) is an intense empowering self-esteem, image and spiritual growth workshop series that is offered to young people and directly addresses this issue.

The workshops are designed to help young people explore the challenges they are facing growing up in today’s complex world and to help them to navigate the numerous choices they will have to make in their young lives, in order to achieve their dreams and ambitions.

The purpose of the program is to open up the minds of these young people and expose them to the world beyond their neighborhood and communities.

The way young people view themselves and their bodies, demands that they have the survival tools that are necessary so that they can achieve their goals and dreams in life. Through BFIO they will learn self-worth, obtain and learn how to value themselves, along with skill building projects.

This program is very popular with the youth because of the workshops and the work they do from the inside/out. They don't realize how the work will impact them until they use the tools they have learned in the real world.

For more about our programs visit us on the web:

 www.ctddreams.org

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

•Everyone has something to give no matter what your situation.

•Make noise about our campaign please! Tell everyone you know on social networking sites about us and the work we are doing.

•Post our links to your presence on the web and keep us in prayer.

 Thank you so much for your help.

 FOR THOSE WHO MAY SUSPECT SOMEONE OF OR ARE THEMSELVES A VICTIM OF HUMAN TRAFFICKING

 In Sacramento contact: WEAVE @ 916-920-2952 or the National Human Trafficking Hotline Center @ 1-888-373-7888.

story:
What is it?

 

RememberWell is a website with two purposes: It functions as an end-of-life library dedicated to "green" and alternative choices, plus it offers web space and a template for hosting and creating an online memorial built by the user.

 

The site is being produced to help people discover what services are available for their transition or the transition of a loved one. It is a one-stop resource programmed so that the user will have an account enabling him or her to "like" their discoveries and return in the future, near or far, to find them neatly organized into easy-to-find categories. Whether you are seeking pre-planning information such as how to choose hospice care or who to call for help with writing your life-story, need-it-now information such as where to find a"green" casket or a "threshold" choir, or follow-up information such as where to find grief support or hand-made urns, RememberWell will make the process an effortless endeavor.

 

The online memorial template will allow for service information as well as biographies, photos, videos, guestbooks, and a space to leave offerings such as a virtual flower bouquet. The user can choose if the commemoration is public or private. Yet, unlike social media, all data and information is never shared or sold behind the scenes. We believe in adhering to strict privacy standards.

 

 

Why are we building it?

 

At the moment, one must spend hours piecing together information regarding eco-friendly, extraordinary end-of-life choices. Oftentimes, one waits until one has to "deal with it" to know what his or her options are. RememberWell aims to make discovering the requisite information so easy that instead of it being a "have to" subject, it becomes a "want to" subject. No rational, healthy person wants to die but since we all will have to cross that threshold, why not be informed and responsible for your exit? Why not make your passing eloquent and expressive, true to your own taste, and inspiring for all concerned? RememberWell can help you do this and provide help to those caring for they dying.

 

 

Why do we need the money?

 

Implementing the redesign. Coding. Hosting. Marketing. Time. We need the time to research, catalogue, and verify legitimate goods and services. And we want to further add in resources such as material on funeral customs, history, and philosophies.

 

Our goal is to provide information and memorial space that is of value and relevance to everyone in need. We hope our service is seen as a no-fuss, easy-to-use website where the focus is on the end-of-life particulars or person being commemorated rather than on clever design. We want the functionality to be seamless. so that the user doesn't even notice it.

story:
Last Frontier Agency, often described as The Marketplace for Good, needs a new website. Our site, now disabled, needs a new look, updated information and our marketplace redeveloped. Since 2007, we have survived by word of mouth, facebook and twitter. Though our vision and mission has been carried out with success, we now are at a point where this folk-style network does not keep up with our demands. That is, we need too  keep up with our growth, and a new website is the answer.

Last Frontier Agency works in various countries in Central & South America, Europe and the African continent. As you can imagine our operating costs are great and we do not want our programs to suffer by taking funds away to pay for a new site. True, the site will expand our reach and multiply our efforts, and yet, we are not willing to take even one step backwards to make it happen. This is, of course, why we are reaching out to you.

While our site is down, you can visit www.nateallenwilson.com, our founder's personal site and photography portfolio.

About Last Frontier Agency

Last Frontier Agency is an education, volunteer and advocacy organization devoted to expanding the worldviews of participants through service to others.

We exist to show people what they may not otherwise have the opportunity to see. LFA offers an experience of truth through service and personal interaction with what we believe to be the most important and last frontier-humanity.

Last Frontier Agency's commitments:

Service to other is in accordance with the teachings of Jesus Christ.

True service involves justice for the poor, weak and widowed.

Service demands non-violence, self-sacrifice and education as the means for social change.

Human Rights  will never manifest its nature in society until we regain a since of civility towards each other, recapture a passionate love for respect and an effective rejection for indifference. This general attitude of adventure set apart from duty is nothing new but it is now a surging trend to be a traveler for humanitarian purposes without really participating in it. As a result, the understanding of human rights is on a continuing down slope and beginning to lose its identification and integrity—habitually preferring trend to reality.

Traditionally understood as inalienable or fundamental, human rights, whichever words one chooses to define with, are inherently entitled to persons not for any reason but that he or she has been born a human being. Therefore, the essence of human rights is not indicative of an individual worth, as described by society, but rather because of a birthright. That is, human rights, or, the rights of a human are as complete and personal as they are universal and egalitarian.

How your contributions help

By contributing to this project you are enabling people's efforts to help those in need, experience a new culture, and broaden countless worldviews.

Since 2008, Last Frontier Agency has been taking groups of volunteers, humanitarians, missionaries and photographers around the world. We have worked in orphanages in South Africa, celebrated holidays with the Serer people in Senegal, encouraged underprivileged children in Dublin, Ireland, gave Nicaraguan families their first portraits and worked with squatters in Natal, Brazil. And, this is only a small portion of what we're doing.

By participating with us in this fundraising campaign, you are effectively allowing us to expand. In fact, you can be assured that this new site will help with the following.

  • Expand our network.
  • Share our stories.
  • Adopt micro projects
  • Offer opportunities to more hopeful travelers.
  • List the needs of our targeted people groups.
  • Collect donations.

Currently, each of these areas are only partially expressed. Because much of our networking is by word of mouth, there is not a single location, like a website, that people can view all of our information.
story_txt:
Last Frontier Agency, often described as The Marketplace for Good, needs a new website. Our site, now disabled, needs a new look, updated information and our marketplace redeveloped. Since 2007, we have survived by word of mouth, facebook and twitter. Though our vision and mission has been carried out with success, we now are at a point where this folk-style network does not keep up with our demands. That is, we need too  keep up with our growth, and a new website is the answer.
Last Frontier Agency works in various countries in Central & South America, Europe and the African continent. As you can imagine our operating costs are great and we do not want our programs to suffer by taking funds away to pay for a new site. True, the site will expand our reach and multiply our efforts, and yet, we are not willing to take even one step backwards to make it happen. This is, of course, why we are reaching out to you.
While our site is down, you can visit www.nateallenwilson.com, our founder's personal site and photography portfolio.
About Last Frontier Agency
Last Frontier Agency is an education, volunteer and advocacy organization devoted to expanding the worldviews of participants through service to others.
We exist to show people what they may not otherwise have the opportunity to see. LFA offers an experience of truth through service and personal interaction with what we believe to be the most important and last frontier-humanity.
Last Frontier Agency's commitments:
Service to other is in accordance with the teachings of Jesus Christ.
True service involves justice for the poor, weak and widowed.
Service demands non-violence, self-sacrifice and education as the means for social change.
Human Rights  will never manifest its nature in society until we regain a since of civility towards each other, recapture a passionate love for respect and an effective rejection for indifference. This general attitude of adventure set apart from duty is nothing new but it is now a surging trend to be a traveler for humanitarian purposes without really participating in it. As a result, the understanding of human rights is on a continuing down slope and beginning to lose its identification and integrity—habitually preferring trend to reality.
Traditionally understood as inalienable or fundamental, human rights, whichever words one chooses to define with, are inherently entitled to persons not for any reason but that he or she has been born a human being. Therefore, the essence of human rights is not indicative of an individual worth, as described by society, but rather because of a birthright. That is, human rights, or, the rights of a human are as complete and personal as they are universal and egalitarian.
How your contributions help
By contributing to this project you are enabling people's efforts to help those in need, experience a new culture, and broaden countless worldviews.
Since 2008, Last Frontier Agency has been taking groups of volunteers, humanitarians, missionaries and photographers around the world. We have worked in orphanages in South Africa, celebrated holidays with the Serer people in Senegal, encouraged underprivileged children in Dublin, Ireland, gave Nicaraguan families their first portraits and worked with squatters in Natal, Brazil. And, this is only a small portion of what we're doing.
By participating with us in this fundraising campaign, you are effectively allowing us to expand. In fact, you can be assured that this new site will help with the following.

Expand our network.
Share our stories.
Adopt micro projects
Offer opportunities to more hopeful travelers.
List the needs of our targeted people groups.
Collect donations.
Currently, each of these areas are only partially expressed. Because much of our networking is by word of mouth, there is not a single location, like a website, that people can view all of our information.

story:
THE PROJECT:

A Culture of Coffee is a transmedia project about the history of coffee and the traditions tied to this major world export, from its origins in Ethiopia and deep national roots to its influence around the globe. By harnessing social and visual media, as well as the rare art of book-making, we explore the oft-ignored imprint of Ethiopian coffee across time and cultures. We consider coffee as a cultural good; not just an everyday caffeine fix, but a fixture, in and of itself. 

THE PURPOSE:

In America, the idea of coffee is often just a quick "cup of Joe" from the corner Starbucks, but in Ethiopia, the history of coffee is as rich as its taste.

For centuries, the artfully-practiced Ethiopian coffee ceremony has been a feast for all five senses: seeing the process of coffee-making from roast to grind to cup; the smell of incense and slow roasted coffee; the sound of conversation and feeling amidst gathered friends. The coffee ceremony creates a culture all its own; an opportunity to forge social bonds, share customs and exchange ideas. And it is this experience of making and consuming coffee that is the centerpiece of a beautiful and time-honored Ethiopian ritual. It's what coffee at its finest should do, simultaneously enliven taste-buds and engage communities.

Championing this culture of coffee is now our cause. By exploring the East African country and its deep-rooted relationship with the coffee bean, we hope to bridge cultural divides and open the lines of communication. As we learn the story behind each sip, we intend to bring a little of Ethiopia to the rest of the world.

THE PLAN:

Our ultimate goal for A Culture of Coffee is to produce several multimedia productions that celebrate the ancient history and culture of coffee in Ethiopia, specifically its unique coffee ceremony, culminating in an artful coffee table book which will be entitled From Ethiopia with Love. To reach as wide an audience as possible, the project will be produced in multiple formats: short video, PDF, hard copy book and limited-edition pop-up. The intention is to make this production as accessible and media rich as possible, including photographs, illustrations and custom design.

However, like the ceremony, itself, the process of exploring Ethiopian coffee culture takes time. 

As we research and develop our project, we hope to reignite the essential ingredient behind coffee--conversation. Understanding the cross-cultural connection that coffee creates requires the kind of dialogue that we will encourage throughout the course of the project. Through our blog and website we invite participants to submit original coffee inspired works of art and photography for the opportunity to become potential co-contributors to the project. As we investigate the provenance, traditions and successors of "buna," we want to share our findings and discuss your personal experiences.

For too long, tea has gotten all the glory. Get ready to experience everything that coffee is made of.

THE FUNDS:

Your generous contributions for this campaign will go directly towards the research and development. A second campaign will be launched afterward to cover production and distribution of From Ethiopia with Love... 

PHASE 1: This first Indiegogo campaign launch covers fundraising for research and development. We'll be connecting people to the culture and promoting awareness through the blog and social media. Most of our budget in this phase will be spent on round trip tickets, room and board, while touring the coffee producing regions of Ethiopia (Sidamo, Yirgacheffe, Harar, Limu, and Jimma) where we will learn about, photograph and film coffee at the source.

PHASE 2: A return from our research trip in Ethiopia will kickoff the design, production and publishing process, which will include the bulk of the costs from our prospective budget ($10,000 for 100 books). The funds raised in our second phase of fundraising will go toward graphic design, photography, illustration, video production and publishing costs to ensure that the project can be accessed in various formats. 

PHASE 3: Once the book is completed, any remaining portions of the budget will cover the costs of a book release in order to celebrate the book's launch and give you a taste of Ethiopian culture--and coffee, of course.We'll release the book and deliverables, using the portion of book sale proceeds towards our Ethiopian Cultural Development Corp seed and startup money, which will be dedicated to preserving and advancing Ethiopian cultural heritage.

THE AUTHOR:

Metasebia Yoseph is the founder and creative director of the Muse Collective, a creative consulting company based in Washington, DC. As a first-generation Ethiopian American this project allows her to combine her art-historical background and curatorial practice with her love of coffee and Ethiopian history. She hopes to use A Culture of Coffee as a springboard for ECDCorp, a cultural development corporation that she co-founded to preserve, conserve, and further Ethiopian cultural heritage.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get  

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Introducing Anzovin Rig Tools

If you're a CG animator, you're probably familiar with the concept of "rigging," the structure inside a character that deforms it's surface and gives you the controls you'll use to manipulate and pose the character. You're also probably familiar with how maddeningly complex and arcane character rigging can be.

Anzovin Rig Tools (or ART) is a completely new way to rig in Autodesk's Maya that is designed from the ground up to handle the complexity of a modern rig. Our toolset includes:

Ground-breaking, spline-based deformation with stretchy, bendable bones that any animator can reshape as needed.

Simplified weight painting.

High-level deformation control.

Volume preservation to easily deform thick objects.

Take a look at the Anzovin Rig Tools website for in-depth info.

New Rigging Tools for a New Century

Modeling, dynamics, shading, and rendering techniques have made great strides in the last decade, but our rigging and animation tools have remained largely stagnant. Sure, we've had some evolutionary usability enhancements, but the basic workflow and functionality offered in tools like Maya isn't really much different then it was in the late 90s.

ART takes character rigging into the 21st century. It will be of immense benefit to anyone who needs to rig expressive and believable characters, from students and freelancers who need a fast and easy way to deform their characters, to experienced rigging professionals who want to add high-level tools to their pipeline.

What We Need & What You Get

Reinventing the rigging and character deformation process turns out to be pretty expensive and time consuming. We've already worked on ART for more then three years now, but we've still got a long way to go--we need to do optimization, tooling, and GUI building before we can even consider ART to be an alpha product, let alone get it into beta testing.

Unfortunately, we're a very small studio, so we're continually getting distracted by the stuff that pays the bills--work-for-hire animation and smaller tools (like our new onion skinning toolset and our auto-rigging tools) that are much cheaper to make. If we're going to get ART out in some reasonable time frame, we're going to need some funding that lets us devote focused time and energy to preparing it for release. And that's where you come in!

We're offering discount codes to everyone who helps us push development on ART forward. Not only can you help us get ART into your hands quicker, you can also save money at the same time.

The higher teirs also offer inclusion to our alpha and beta programs. Note that while ART will be available for all platforms that support Maya 2011 and up, the alpha version will be limited to 64-bit Maya running under Windows.

Our Timeline

ART is new technology founded on complex algorithms, so it's difficult to be precise about release date. However, if we're able to fully fund ART development, we are aiming to going beta sometime in June for a release this summer. We'll let you know immediately if there are any delays.

Other Things You Can Do To Help

If you're not interested in the ART discount, you can also help us by ordering some of our existing products from our store at http://www.anzovinstore.com/
