story:
$51,761. THAT is the total amount, between our two indiegogo fundraisers, that you all were able to raise in a mere FIVE days... FIVE days!!!! Because you and others like you chose to give back, we have been able to serve 7,394 free, hot meals to people in New York and New Jersey who have no power and, in some of the worst cases, no homes.

You all are incredible and from the very bottoms of our hearts, we thank you for your incredible generosity.


Today, ten days after Super Storm Sandy struck, many are still living without lights and heat so we are continuing to serve via our partnership with The NYC Mayor's Fund to Advance NYC and several corporate sponsors. If you would still like to help bring hot meals to NY-ers, you can donate to the Mayors Fund and ask them to earmark the money for food truck emergency outreach.

Thank you and take care. 

 ____

Overview

In the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, the New York City Food Truck Association (NYCFTA) worked with Jetblue to deliver over 20,000 meals to our neighbors in NY and NJ without power.  Inspired, we decided to reach out to the community to keep the outreach going in the most severely affected areas on the coast of Staten Island, Queens, & Brooklyn. In just two days, the global community responded in great force and we were able to raise over $27,000, more than TRIPLING the amount we  anticipated. We are incredibly thankful and want to keep the momentum going as there are still thousands without power.

Here is how we've helped on the ground so far:

On Friday 11/2, Jetblue gave out hot meals to 11k people without power in Lower Manhattan and Brooklyn via 12 sponsored trucks.  

On Saturday 11/3, Jetblue distributed hot meals to 10k people in Brooklyn, Staten Island, and Hoboken, NJ, via 11 sponsored 11 trucks.

On Sunday 11/4 Jetblue distributed hot meals to 4k people in the Rockaways via 4 food trucks. NYC Food Truck Association raised money so fast from people like you via our last promotion, we were able to get 2 trucks out to deliver 1k more meals the same day.  

On Monday 11/5, we have eight trucks out to distribute hot meals to 3k people in Staten Island, the Rockaways, and Redhook.

Many individuals and businesses have written and asked if it is still possible to donate... and the answer is: Yes you can! And we will put your money to use immediately getting hot meals to those who need them.

What We Need

Food trucks are small businesses that are run by resourceful and caring entrepreneurs.  They have the desire and infrastructure to help, but not the resources to do as much as they might like.  Working with sponsors and the larger community helps us make a larger impact in helping those who are still suffering from the storm.  We are looking for sponsorships to pay for food and fuel for food trucks to go out and serve communities in NYC that were most affected by Super Storm Sandy. 

  • A hot meal from a food truck costs about $7 
  • We are hoping to raise $7,000 to distribute 1,000 meals tomorrow
  • All the money will go towards food and fuel for food trucks to sponsor outreach (minus the administrative costs of indiegogo)

If we cannot raise the full amount we will simply put the money raised towards food and fuel for trucks to donate what they can

What You Get

Depending on the amount you contribute you can get all sorts of fun goodies like free high-fives from your favorite truck, a social media shout out as a contributor, or even the ability to choose your favorite NYCFTA truck to serve in an affected communuity.

The Impact

Many communities around NYC have been entirely destroyed by Super Storm Sandy.  A hot meal is a small way to help those who have lost power, water, telephone access, and possibly even their home have a moment of comfort.

  • We can move fast and get help out to those who need it quickly.
  • We have been running outreach to affected communities for the past two days and have delivered more than 20,000 hot meals to those in need.  
  • Just check @nycfoodtruck for all the positive reports from the field about how this outreach has been received so far in areas affected by Sandy

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute, it doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please get the word out about our campaign.
  • Retweet fundraising and support posts on twitter @nycfoodtruck
  • Check out our twitter page: www.twitter.com/nycfoodtruck
  • Like our facebook page: www.facebook.com/nycfoodtrucks
  • Visit our members: www.nycfoodtrucks.org/members

Thanks for taking the time to checkout and support the work we've been doing.

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can’t contribute, it doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Please get the word out about our campaign.
Retweet fundraising and support posts on twitter @nycfoodtruck
Check out our twitter page: www.twitter.com/nycfoodtruck

Like our facebook page: www.facebook.com/nycfoodtrucks

Visit our members: www.nycfoodtrucks.org/members



Thanks for taking the time to checkout and support the work we've been doing.

story:
In the last week of Feb. 2013 I went in the hospital with an obstructed bowel.  It turned out the obstruction was a couple of cancerous leisions.  They removed the affected portion of the bowel but they didn't know where the cancer arose from.  So my oncologist has recommended I get chemo and I start on April 3rd.  I'm looking at six months of chemo which means six months of nausea, drugs, and anxiety.  I have no idea how I am going to react to the drugs and the treatment in general, but I do know that I need something to look forward to so that I can get through this ordeal better.  My plan is to take my long time girlfriend on a vacation, hopefully to the beach, after I finish with the chemo.  She's been indispensible in this ordeal and frankly I could not have made it this far without her, so I want to do something nice for her and for me for having to go through all this.

I figure a nice condo at Atlantic Beach, NC is going to cost around $800 to $900 a week and we'll need to money for groceries.  I'm already on a very fixed income and what little disposable income I have I am using to pay off the various medical bills that Medicare doesn't cover.  So I need to find another source of funds to pay for this vacation, that's where you come in.  If you can donate anything at all to help me go on this much needed trip to the beach then I'm eternally grateful.  Any donation is appreciated and if you donate $10 I'll send you a sticker from my line of vintage stickers.  If you donate $20 you get a vintage line sticker and a sticker from my linocut collection.  If you donate $50, you get the stickers and an original illustration.  If you donate $75 you get the stickers, an illustration, and an 8" x 10" print of one of my artsy photos. 

Iknow many others have it worse than me but I really need something to look forward to during all these months of chemo and recovery from getting part of my bowel removed.  And I want to do something nice for my hardworking girlfriend.  So, please, if you can spare it, toss me a few bucks and help me go on vacation in the fall after I get done with chemo.

story:
What is a Botanica:

A botánica is a retail store that sells folk medicine, religious candles and statuary, amulets, and other products regarded as magical or as alternative medicine. They also carry oils, incense, perfumes, scented sprays,baths,soaps,floor washes, and other such items.

Botánicas can be found in any United States city, though most commonly those with ties to the Caribbean. The number of botánicas found outside of New York and Miami has grown tremendously in the last ten years.

The name botánica is Spanish and translates as "botany" or "plant" store, referring to these establishments' function as dispensaries of medicinal herbs. Medicinal herbs may be sold dried or fresh, prepackaged or in bulk.

Who we are: Our names are Anthony, Franklin, Joseph, and Joshua. We met in New Orleans, Louisanna, through a local, tight-knit spiritual comunity. Between the four of us, we hold a lifetime of expert knowledge and experience, and we have bonded over the shared goal and vision to open up a Botanica in the cty that is our home.
 

Where we come from: We have seen a great lack of represention of Black and Brown business owners, as well as authentically and community focused integrity, in the sea of occult and voodoo shops that make up the city of New Orleans; that is why it is very imortant to us to be a strong and postive representation in our community. Many of our business partners are POC. We feel that it is Integral for us as local small-business owners to accurately represent our long historical presence in this city, and the religions that ulitmately lead to our mental and spiritual freedom from our oppressors, long before our bodies were those of free people.
 

What we are asking: Though we are very hard-working and determined people with a strong plan, and the motivation to accomplish and execute our goals, we recognize that we are at somewhat of a financial disadvantage to the exsisting owners of many similiar bussinesses aready present here in New Orleans. That is where y'all come in:  with your help—donations and promotion—we deeply feel that we can indeed provide a physical and spiritual experience unlike any other in North America. 
 

What sets us apart?: Two of our partners are trained chefs and mixologists, capable of distilling spirits, creating dishes and cocktails that majorly relate to our goal of providing physical and spiritual healing and growth to the people of New Orleans. Besides our accrued vast spiritual practice, knowledge, and abilites, we feel that our culinary edge really what sets us apart from other businesses in our field. 
We intend to offer food and libations, with the combined goal of helping our guests and clients achive a better quality of life, holistic and spiritual wellness, all in a relaxed, comfortable environment. We also will offer psychic and tarot readings, consultations on physical and spiritual wellness, lectures, workshops, custom client work, as well as both public and private events.
 

How you can help: We can not stress how important your donations and support are to our success in a social and political climate such as New Orleans. As you likely all know, we have been through a lot, both as a city and as individuals. This history is why we feel there is such a need for what we have to offer as a business. Well-being and healing should be accessible to everyone, with an emphasis on the historical significance and awareness of the people within the city. Your donations can help bring that—an answer to the needs of a still very damaged, yet vibrant, community.
Local business stimulates local economy, as well as independent growth of persons therein. We want to be honest with you; while we have a lot to lose as individuals, we firmly believe that we possess what it takes to make these dreams a successful reality, and your donations and support in spreading the word about this crowdfunding venture can play a key roll in cementing our success. 
 

Our Goal: We aim to raise as close to $10,000.00 as possible both through this crowd funding platform and through comunity fundraising events—such as themed social gatherings and other services. what those funds would help us acchive are the fabrication of integral fixtures, as well as remodeling/renovating of our space. The purchase of all the small parts that make up a well-stocked and comprehensive boatinica, as well as obtaining all necessary licenses and permits required to operate such a space. 
 

Thank You! : We humbly and gratefully ask you to donate what you can to aid in the success of our venture. If you see this and are not in a place finacially to donate, yet you are into what we are doing, please, please, please use the share functions provided by Indiegogo. Thank you so much for your time, interest, word-of-mouth support, and donations. We hope that in blessing us, you are blessed abundantly in return.
story_txt: What is a Botanica:A botánica is a retail store that sells folk medicine, religious candles and statuary, amulets, and other products regarded as magical or as alternative medicine. They also carry oils, incense, perfumes, scented sprays,baths,soaps,floor washes, and other such items.Botánicas can be found in any United States city, though most commonly those with ties to the Caribbean. The number of botánicas found outside of New York and Miami has grown tremendously in the last ten years.The name botánica is Spanish and translates as "botany" or "plant" store, referring to these establishments' function as dispensaries of medicinal herbs. Medicinal herbs may be sold dried or fresh, prepackaged or in bulk.Who we are: Our names are Anthony, Franklin, Joseph, and Joshua. We met in New Orleans, Louisanna, through a local, tight-knit spiritual comunity. Between the four of us, we hold a lifetime of expert knowledge and experience, and we have bonded over the shared goal and vision to open up a Botanica in the cty that is our home. Where we come from: We have seen a great lack of represention of Black and Brown business owners, as well as authentically and community focused integrity, in the sea of occult and voodoo shops that make up the city of New Orleans; that is why it is very imortant to us to be a strong and postive representation in our community. story:
Celebrate with me!

I am biking from New York City to Los Angeles this summer to celebrate turning 40 and completing my PhD at MIT after 14 years of college! It's gonna cost $3k and I am a poor (sson to be ex) graduate student, so any help would be greatly appreciated!

story:
About Amy and Derek

When we first got married back in 2004, we took a little time to enjoy our new life together, and then, like many newly-married couples, decided a year or so later that we were ready to start our family!  We both had baby-fever.  We were so excited about the start of this journey to parenthood.  But as time dragged on, we started to get concerned.  We never dreamed it would be such a challenge. 

So we went to doctors who kept assuring they could see nothing that was wrong, and that it would happen.  We were patient, listened to everyone's advice, and waited.  But it didn't happen.  Our doctor agreed to try clomid to up our chances.  And after this first fertility treatment, it finally happened!  We were overjoyed!  But the joy was short-lived.  Amy suffered an ectopic pregnancy which resulted in some long-term damage.

Thus began a five-year journey filled with doctor appointments, shots, surgeries, miscarriages, fertility treatments, medical bills, and many highs and lows.  It's been a tough road emotionally and financially.  But through it all we've been surrounded by many supportive friends and family members, and have stayed strong and have stayed hopeful that this will happen one way or another.  

And by being open about our struggles, we have even been able to share what we've learned and provide guidance and support to many friends and friends-of-friends who have dealt with their own infertility struggles.  And happily, many of their journeys have ended in success!

Recently, we started exploring new options and new doctors.  After much research and many interviews we are finally working with a new doctor and have a new plan, and we really do believe that this next step on our journey will be a successful one!

 

About the Fundraising Effort

We are doing all we can to raise the resources needed for this next phase of our journey, and we are reaching out to friends, family and well-wishers to raise a portion of the money through fundraising so we can more quickly reach our goal of becoming parents and having a family of our own. 

We've set a goal for the site of $7,500.  The total cost of our next step will be approximately $20,000, including in-vitro fertilization costs, medications, and doctor fees.  All contributions will help us move closer to our goal!  

 

Gifts ('Perks') for You!

While we hope everyone receives some good karma and warm fuzzy feelings for donating, we wanted to try and give some more tangible things back to our support-givers as well.  

Some generous friends and family members have donated talents, services, or items to this page to offer as 'perks' to people contributing different levels of donations.  If you donate and there are perks left at your level, please choose one!  We will either deliver the gift to you, or arrange for a drop-off or pick-up if it is something like food or an item.  We will continue to update the page with donated gifts as well since many items are of a limited quantity.

 

The Impact

Having run into this roadblock in our life plan has been a huge emotional and financial challenge for us.  It has left us feeling like we've been running in circles for a long time.  We truly appreciate all of your support and look forward to sharing some happy news with everyone down the line.  We are more than ready to move on to the family phase of our life and enjoy all of the fun, stress, laughs, tears, sleeplessness, silliness, love, and joy that comes with being parents :)

story:
Software for managing church membership and accounting records are expensive and difficult to use. Church treasurers and clerks are not often expert accountants or record keepers. So, why do the tools designed to help them do their work assume that they are?

Church Roll makes a different assumption. It assumes that church treasurers, clerks and anyone else serving small churches would rather be doing ministry than administration. So, the software is designed to be easy and to automate as much as possible.

Currently available software for church management and accounting cost any where from $250 to over $500 per year. Only a few of those solutions provide membership and accounting features. And, even fewer are web-based. Leaving it to the church to figure out how to keep the data secure, how to manage backups and how to handle upgrades. So many of the solutions today give churches more work to do, instead of less.

As a web-based solution, Church Roll doesn't create new work for churches. All data is stored securely and backed up automatically. Additionally, there's no software to install. So, churches don't have to manage upgrades because Church Roll is always at the latest version. And, Church Roll plans to offer this for under $15 per month, with discounts for church planters and very small churches.

Church Roll is a better solution to the needs of churches. But, it needs some help. Development of the project has been hampered by the fact that it has been a hobby project up until now. So, Church Roll needs your help to get really rolling with some full-time development focus and beta testing. And, if you choose to support, there are some great perks available!

Perks

  • Everyone who contributes $1 or more will be invited to the priavate beta that should open in October.
  • 10% Off Forever voucher will be given to everyone who contributes at least $10.
  • 25% Off Forever voucher will be given to everyone who contributes at least $50.
  • 1 Year + 50% Off Forever voucher will be given to everyone who contributes at least $100.
  • Lifetime voucher will be given to everyone who contributes at least $500.

For denominational bodies, like local associations and state conventions, they can receive a customized package of vouchers and a limited number of private beta invitations for any contributions of at least $250. As an example an association that contributes $250 could choose 25 10% Off Forever vouchers, or 5 25% Off Forever Vouchers, or some combination of the other support levels to meet their goals regarding serving the churches in their fellowship.

story:
Short Summary

I'm Larry Mattson, president of the board of the new Terra Sol Sports Alliance. In the summer of 2012, a group of soccer-crazed, civic-minded friends and I got together to build a soccer complex in the Yakima Valley. We recently elected a board and selected Terra Sol Sports Alliance as our name.

Why the name? We lead the nation in cherries, apples, hops; we average 300 days of sun per year; and we welcome all soccer clubs and programs, as well as soccer-compatible sports like lacrosse, rugby, and football.

Soccer is incredibly popular here in the Valley. So much so that many of our facilities are over-used, and the field conditions show it. Our vision is to "provide a world class soccer facility that welcomes all sports, all teams and all players to participate in physical activity in a safe and friendly atmosphere."

Why soccer, why here, and why now?

  • Because soccer brings together people of different cultures like few sports can.
  • Because youth obesity is on the rise and we need kids to get up and get active.
  • Because gangs are an attractive option to kids who have no outlet for their energy and we need after-school sports programs.

Your contribution lays the foundation for an enduring community asset, allowing us to finalize our non-profit status. We are drafting business and strategic plans to guide our work. We'll select a location as those plans are finalized, by working with local municipalities and private landowners.

What We Need & What You Get

In Phase 1, we are raising $5,000 in order to:

  • Submit and finalize our state and federal 501(c)3 non-profit charitable organization paperwork
  • Finalize our logo to develop stationery and initial marketing materials (think t-shirts, soccer balls, and caps)
  • Develop our website in order to get the word out and keep our friends informed of our progress

If we don't reach our goal, the funds will be used to pay as much of the state and federal fees as possible.

In Phase 2, we'll be seeking funding for designing the complex. We anticipate this phase to cost $75,000-$100,000.

Phase 3 is our capital campaign, likely between $10 and $20 million. This will fund development costs. Any remaining funds will be set aside in a foundation. Foundation funds will be used primarily to enhance youth access to soccer and complementary sports such as lacrosse, field hockey, and rugby.

The Impact

Yakima makes sense for a soccer complex:

  • Equal travel time from the metro Seattle, Spokane, and Vancouver areas
  • A warm, welcoming, sports-friendly community
  • A growing community that already hosts two sold-out soccer tournaments every summer (Yak Attack; Mid-Summer Classic).

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute and would like to help, send us a note. We are always interested in technical assistance from the legal, financial/accounting, and construction disciplines.

  • Don't forget to share, tweet, or "like" us with your friends
  • Indiegogo makes it easy with their share tools!

story:
Dear Friends, Family & Colleagues,

 

It only feels right to re-introduce myself, although most you know me well. But for those who don’t, my name is Lauren Brown Jarvis. I’m a writer, content creator and lover of all things related to technology and communications. I blog regularly on the intersection of women and technology, as well as, my own adventures at www.digitaldoyennes.com.

 

You’re probably not familiar with the word “doyenne”. It’s a french word that quite simply references a woman who is either senior in rank, or the best at what she does. It’s a title I’ve donned proudly since I launched the concept in April of 2011, when I hosted, “Digital Doyennes: Wisdom from the Women Who Lead in Social Media & Digital Innovation.” Hosting this event was the pinnacle of my career in the digital space. 

 I feel confident the next peak I will scale will be that of making my way to Kampala, Uganda to be a presenter at TEDxKiraTownWomen. I’ll be speaking on the theme “The Space in Between”. The space I’ll be exploring is between social and media and how women fit in between.

 

Uganda is one of the world's poorest nations, with a majority of its citizens living on less than $1.25/day. Most of the impoverished are rural women. Rural women in Uganda often work much harder than their male counterparts, overseeing agricultural tasks and caring for their families, obtaining food, water, firewood. There is a desire on their parts to be entrepreneurial, and this is not just for rural women, but all Ugandan women. It is therefore of utmost importance that I speak to all the ways new, digital and social media are making commerce and business ownership possible for women all over the globe.

 

This is where I need your help. In order to be able to share some insight with the women of Uganda, I must first raise the funds to get there.

 

Two nights of my accommodations are being covered by the TEDxKiraTownWomen organizers. However, my airfare and accompanying travel expenses are not. While I will only be speaking on one day, Saturday, December 1, 2012, this is a tremendous opportunity for me to also make my first visit to the “Motherland” and my hope is that while there, I will get to explore the “Pearl of Africa” as Uganda is often called.

 

Where The Money Is Going:

  • Roundtrip Airfare to Entebbe, Uganda from Atlanta, Georgia 
  • Three night accommodations at the Prestige Apartments in Kampala 
  • Visa Entry Fees to Uganda 
  • Taxi fares to, from airport, TEDxKiraTownWomen et al.
  • Meals!

 

What Happens If I Exceed My Goal:

Any dollars raised outside of my expenses will be donated to the non-profit, Ugandan American Partnership Organization’s (UAPO) Akola Project. The Akola Project is an economic development initiative that helps rural Ugandan women generate sustainable income for themselves and their families. I was introduced to UAPO through founder Brittany Merrill. Brittany has dedicated her career to serving rural women of Uganda and and I am moved to support this effort through her work.

 

Other Ways To Help!

Donations in all sizes are welcome, however, sharing this campaign with your friends and colleagues is also needed and appreciated.  Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn or an old-fashioned email, any way to spread the word will all serve to help me reach my goal.

  

All the Best,

Lauren Brown Jarvis

story:
What is Pitch & Match?

Pitch&Match is the first student-organized networking platform where investment professionals are connected to inspiring social entrepreneurs in the Netherlands with innovative sustainable business ideas. The goal of the project is to provide both social entrepreneurs and investors with a unique opportunity to expand their network and a possibility to embark on further relations. The event will be arranged in the format of the Famous BBC “Dragons‘ Den” whereby six best social entrepreneurs who passed the selection process present their innovative ideas in 3 minutes, in front of a panel of strong and experienced investors. The investors will give feedback and select, together with the audience, the best pitch of the evening. After that there will be space for informal networking, “borrel” and entertainment program, e.g. live music and many other surprises!

Where and when

The up-coming event will take place in de Zuiderkerk in Amsterdam on December 10th, 2012. Doors open at 7pm.

What We Need & What You Get

Pitch&Match is a part of the Socionext Foundation. The mission of Socionext is to engage university students in the Netherlands directly with their South African counterparts and find creative ways to provide funding for the South African funds Studietrust and TSiBA.
Socionext breaks away from the traditional charity-based approach to “helping” Africa: by now the world has realized that the principle of equality, mutual engagement and creating shared value contributes much more to sustainable development. Pitch&Match is one of the results of this mission.

As students we are dependent on people who share our strong belief that a positive change in this world is possible and lies in our own hands. If you want to support our and Socionext’s cause and want to meet other inspirational changemakers at this exciting event, your participation will be highly appreciated! Let's make this world a better place

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and tell all your friends about Pitch&Match!
story_txt:
What is Pitch & Match?
Pitch&Match is the first student-organized networking platform where investment professionals are connected to inspiring social entrepreneurs in the Netherlands with innovative sustainable business ideas. The goal of the project is to provide both social entrepreneurs and investors with a unique opportunity to expand their network and a possibility to embark on further relations. The event will be arranged in the format of the Famous BBC “Dragons‘ Den” whereby six best social entrepreneurs who passed the selection process present their innovative ideas in 3 minutes, in front of a panel of strong and experienced investors. The investors will give feedback and select, together with the audience, the best pitch of the evening. After that there will be space for informal networking, “borrel” and entertainment program, e.g. live music and many other surprises!
Where and when
The up-coming event will take place in de Zuiderkerk in Amsterdam on December 10th, 2012. Doors open at 7pm.


What We Need & What You Get
Pitch&Match is a part of the Socionext Foundation. The mission of Socionext is to engage university students in the Netherlands directly with their South African counterparts and find creative ways to provide funding for the South African funds Studietrust and TSiBA. Socionext breaks away from the traditional charity-based approach to “helping” Africa: by now the world has realized that the principle of equality, mutual engagement and creating shared value contributes much more to sustainable development. Pitch&Match is one of the results of this mission.
As students we are dependent on people who share our strong belief that a positive change in this world is possible and lies in our own hands. If you want to support our and Socionext’s cause and want to meet other inspirational changemakers at this exciting event, your participation will be highly appreciated! Let's make this world a better place


Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word and tell all your friends about Pitch&Match!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
TAKE A LOOK AT OUR INTERESTING PRESENTION CLICK THE LINK BELOW:

http://prezi.com/lxixubd0hrzb/bemel-foundation/

 

Hello, Hi, ¡Hola, Kedu, Bonjour, 你好, Ciao, Ẹ n lẹ, Ete-Sen

We are BEMEL.

Who?
BEMEL… BEMEL… B.E.M.E.L

Okay! Who are you?
Apologies;
BEMEL Foundation is a non-profit & non-government organisation that focuses on providing medical services for the local community and combating ignorance in health based issues, through education.

Based in Ibadan, Nigeria; BEMEL started in 1990 by the Ajayis (Mr Emanuel (R.I.P) & Mrs Elizabeth), both experts in the medical field, with over 20 years of experience.
Mr Ajayi was a medical laboratory scientist, who set up one of the most recognised and respected medical laboratory/training schools in Nigeria; Oluyoro Medical Services he also played a significant role as the head of the laboratory department and Chief Medical Scientist at Jaja Health Services within the University of Ibadan.

Mrs Ajayi is an established mid-wife, social worker and qualified nurse is a well known & respected lady in Ibadan, Oyo State.

At the BEMEL Foundation, the medical services provided are;

  • Surgery
  • Obstetrics
  • Gynaecology
  • Paediatrics
  • Diagnostics
  • Immunisation & infant welfare clinic &
  • Free medical events in rural areas
  • Maternal care and malaria awareness is the main area of focus


... BEMEL UK are the overseas representatives for the BEMEL Foundation …

What have you done?

During our 22 years of the foundation, we have strived to provide affordable, quality medical services for the less privileged. To date, we have performed;

  • Over 2000 childbirths
  • 1500+ surgeries &
  • Over 8800 patient admissions and general treatments

We have also educated members of the public through;

  • General health education
  • Antenatal clinics
  • Counselling for women &
  • Malaria eradication campaigns.

ALL this has been done through personal funds & the kindness of donors.

But it does not end there, we hope to get BEMEL to a stage where it will be self-sufficient, for example; in the near future we hope to start small businesses, run by the locals and the profit used to sustain the community and BEMEL.

With time, we hope to build relationships with reputable hospitals across various countries, where we can join hands and provide quality, affordable medical services, for those who otherwise won’t have any.

You seem to be doing well, why should I donate?

…Because our work is not done.
Since the passing of Mr Ajayi (R.I.P), sustaining the BEMEL Foundation has become increasingly difficult. (He took up multiple jobs to fund the foundation whilst he was alive). As of today, the only source of income comes from Mrs Ajayi and a handful of donations received alongside loans which have placed the hospital in debt.

Quality medical services are not readily available in the area BEMEL is located in, resulting in a countless amount of patients seeking alternative options, unfortunately those alternatives end up being bogus hospitals that have been illegally set up, with incompetent doctors and nurses that do not know the difference between a liver and a kidney.
Sadly, most of the patients do not leave the “hospital” alive. 9 out of every 10 hospitals/medical surgeries in the area are illegitimate. l

At the foundation, there are 16+ staff working round the clock to hold up BEMEL; but are hardly paid for their contribution. This is due to the lack of funds available, which has forcefully led to some of the staff to leave BEMEL in search of paying jobs.
In the month of Octoer 2012 the security guard left because of this and we don't want this to continue...losing staff will eventually lead to closing down the hospital. (The combined staff wages alone costs about ₦400000/ £1600 per month)

On a monthly basis, we face the troubling possibility of having to shut BEMEL down; we just don’t have the money to keep BEMEL open, pay the hard working staff and offer a quality service.

In order for the BEMEL foundation to run for 12 months alone, a total of about 12, 000,000N (Naira) equating to £47,400/$76451.48 is needed.

This allows BEMEL to cover the costs over  its 6 main areas of functioning;

  1. Medical costs - (Staff salaries, drugs, equipment, facility maintenance)
  2. Free medical outreach – Drugs, paying doctors invited, canopy rental, PA system, refreshments)
  3. Advocacy Visits – (Transportation, promo printing, gifts)
  4. HIV sensitisation & education campaign – (Educational materials, PA system, refreshments)
  5. Malaria sensitisation & education campaign – (Educational materials, PA system, canopy rentals, insecticide-treated nets)
  6. Marketing/fundraising costs – (Staff time, marketing materials, design & printing, media outreach, sponsor visits)


What will happen to my donation?

Your donation will go towards helping those who cannot afford quality medical services.

For instance, a donation of just £10 (price of a DVD movie), would cover the cost of a health check-up, for 1 person at BEMEL once a month for at least 5 months.

Your donation will also go towards helping pay the BEMEL Foundation staff a salary; improve medical facilities, equipment, re-ignite the medical laboratory and the BEMEL location.


We do not have any major advertising campaign to pay for.
We do not have any debts to pay off.
All of our UK colleagues are volunteers who donate their time, effort and money to BEMEL.

We are not a major charity with budgets and we have nothing to hide. We will always be transparent with every single penny donated.


What happens if we raise more than our target???

If we raise more than our target... Wow!
If we raise more than our target, one of our BEMEL UK volunteers will personally go a....
Ok, maybe we won’t physically do anything (apart from jumping for joy), but it would be a MASSIVE deal & it would mean more money going to a great cause; saving lives.

Furthermore, if you take a quick peek again at the what Bemel really needs to function in a year (see above) you would find that our fundraising target amount ($20,000) is no where near what they really need to support them throughout the year so more money would literally mean more contribution towards keeping Bemel running more efficiently.


What is in it for me?

Good question;
Knowing that your donation is going to help out those who cannot afford, but need the medical services that BEMEL provides,
Knowing that your donation will not be used for the wrong reasons,
Knowing that you are making a huge difference to the lives of people…

… Not forgetting, a choice of goodies, to your left.
Go on… Take a look.

Thank you so much for your time and donation.
 If you have any more questions or just want to know more about BEMEL, please don’t hestitate to contact us on:

Visit the website @:
www.bemelfoundation.org

Add us on Facebook & Like our page on:
http://www.facebook.com/BemelFoundation

Follow us on twitter: @BemelFoundation
https://twitter.com/BemelFoundation

 

PS, all the currency conversions are correct at the time of posting this campaign and hence are subject to fluctuation.

story:
I was born and raised in Sierra Leone, lived in the USA for years. After the Civil War commonly known as the Blood Diamond war in Sierra Leone. Revisited my beloved Sierra Leone and saw the need to help but I thought to myself, I have three children, a job and my own issue how can I, one person make a difference.

Years later meet a good friend Darlis Johnson, encouraged me to go and two weeks later Khadarlis for Sierra Leone was born. 

Khadarlis is that rare Rhode Island non-profit whose international work in war-torn countries like Sierra Leone and Guatemala is matched by its intense focus on local community and neighborhood needs.  In six short years, this all-volunteer organization has undertaken a number of international projects, most of which are based in Sierra Leone, including:

  • building and maintaining clean water wells and indigenous mud-hut dwellings;

  • refurbishing and restocking school libraries;

  • initiating solar energy projects;

  • collecting and widely distributing essential items like food, clothing and computers to families throughout the country;

  • initiating and sustaining a women’s empowerment project centered around palm oil (from initial seeding and cultivation to exporting).

At the same time, Khadarlis has always sustained a local focus, concentrating much of it’s energy on building relationships in Olneyville, North Providence and the neighborhoods around Academy and Valley Streets as well as Rhode Island .  These local efforts have taken the form of,

  • serving as a repository for donated household items (through long-established partnerships with such companies as Good360, Home Depot and Bed, Bath & Beyond) to families and individuals moving out of shelters into permanent housing, to victims of fire, to victims of domestic violence, and to elders at risk. Addressing urgent needs related to child welfare and learning, homelessness (through partnerships with Crossroads, and all CAP (community action partners), among other agencies) and low-income housing;

  • serving as a employment resource center for adults looking for jobs and professional development opportunities through establishing a public computer lab and referral service;

  • providing computers and tutoring for local students through a variety of partnerships in higher education and through the efforts of volunteer educators.

 To really see what we do you should visit our site at http://www.khadarlis.org, and our Facebook pageshttps://www.facebook.com/khadarlis.

With YOUR help we can come together and make a difference. EVERY PENNY COUNTS.

My project 
Bio gas typically refers to a gas produced by the breakdown of organic matter in the absence of oxygen. It is a renewable energy source, like solar and wind energy. Furthermore, bio-gas can be produced from regionally available raw materials and recycled waste and is environmentally friendly.

Goal: to improve people’s lives in rural areas through production of Bio Gas for cooking, heating and lighting while reducing Green House Gasses, avoiding production of charcoal or wood for cooking, reduction of CH 4 and CO2, avoiding slash and burn, avoiding smoke in houses, by using human and agriculture waste in a combined cheap gas producing unit that will costs less than 190 US$ per 2 households. Bio gas production units are natural systems that use organic agricultural waste, primarily manure, to produce bio-gas (fuel) and biol (natural fertilizer) by means of anaerobic digestion. Larger bio-gas production equipment can be used to power electricity generators.

Not only can a family bio gas unit generate renewable and inexpensive energy but it also provides health benefits for the family, because bio-gas does not emit smoke when cooking. In cases where families need to collect firewood, a bio-gas unit can greatly reduce the physical work involved, replaced by the loading of manure and water into the production unit. In agriculture, it provides a farmer with a natural and organic fertilizer which helps increase crop yields, whether vegetables, fruit, corn, potatoes, coffee, onions, cassava, etc. Besides increasing productivity, biol gives ecological added value to products because they can be grown free of chemicals. What is more, farmers or communities save money by not having to buy chemical fertilizers for their crops.

Benefits---health improvement, safer cooking and lighting houses, reduction of CH4 and CO2, better living, healthier living, enjoying life, restful sleep, safer lives and helps the environment.

This DIY equipment provide benefits to families and communities by:

• Reducing the amount of wood fuel used by the household

• Preserving forests that naturally clean the water and air and provide habitats for thousands of species of unique plants and animals, avoiding deforestation

• Producing highquality organic fertilizer as a byproduct

• Improving household air quality by reducing reliance on smoky wood burning stoves

• Providing a method for treating raw waste and finally:

This Do It Yourself Bio-equipment work best when fueled with pig manure, but cow manure,coffee millings, human waste, organic waste as rice husk, sugarcane or cassava waste and any other clean, chemical and pesticide free, biodegradable material can also be used. Biofuel equipment requires about 12 shovels of clean, chemical and contaminant free manure every day.

The Bioequipment

is built with local available materials including a plastic bucket, some plastic bottles, PVC pipes and so on, a release valve is the most expensive part not exceeding US$ 90. A complete list of materials and building manual is available on request.

Sustainable Technology:

As the technology used is simple, it is accessible to anyone, even those with no

prior knowledge. It is enough to follow a few simple instructions to set up this

equipment and understand the technology, the daily operation, maintenance and

repair work. All materials are available locally, without the need to import anything

from abroad.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can volunteer to help promote this cause, you can volunteer at khadarlis.

  • post, share, comment, pass the link to your friends and family.
  • Do not forget use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it. See we care making change together. Thanks

story:
We are excited to announce our new location and Grand Reopening in Sellwood at 8609 SE 17th Avenue, Portland, Oregon 97202. Our projected soft open date is on or after Monday September 2, 2013, followed by our Grand Reopening and 2 Year Anniversary Celebration on September 14, 2013. This space used to be a coffee shop and restaurant, allowing us to easily incorporate new and nourishing items such as organic smoothies, fresh squeezed organic juices, natural deli products, fresh brewed organic tea, organic espresso and organic coffee. The space features a patio and garden with outdoor seating and plenty of sunshine for our garden starts and plants.

Organic Smoothies

It's conveniently located next door to a restaurant called Thia Square. We have tried their food 3 times now and it is highly recommended by us! The owner is excited to create a new organic Thai selection, using our spices, blends and produce. The days of having to fight for a parking spot or scraping your bumper as you pull into our parking lot are over. We will share with Thai Square a paved parking lot with room for 9 cars, 10 bikes and plenty of street parking around the building. Lack of decent and reasonable parking will no longer be an issue! Our new space will now include a public restroom and outdoor seating to enjoy your smoothie, coffee, tea, kombucha, pastry and/or your deli items, which will be made with all natural ingredients.

We are often asked if we accept EBT. The answer has been, "No, sorry but hopefully soon..." That is because we don't stock at least two categories of perishable food items, which is what the government requires before they will allow a business to accept EBT. Vegetable garden starts and produce count as one category to fulfill their requirement, but never have we had a second perishable food category, which has to be either dairy, meat or grain. We need the funding to add another category of perishable food to our selection before we can begin accepting EBT. Nourishing organic and natural foods should be available to everyone.

We will be located close to or on:

  • SE Milwaukie Street/SE 17th Avenue
  • SE Tacoma Street
  • The Springwater Trail
  • Thai Square Restaurant
  • Sellwood Middle School
  • Sellwood Dog Supply
  • Oaks Bottom Forge
  • Piece of Cake
  • Mio Sushi
  • New Seasons Market
  • Sellwood Community Center
  • Mike's Drive In
  • Killer Burger
  • Oaks Amusement Park
  • Goodwill Outlet
  • Waverly Country Club
  • And many more great businesses
  • We're centrally located in Sellwood between
    • 99E
    • Hiway 224
    • West Moreland
    • Sellwood Bridge

New Sellwood Bridge opening 2015

The business which previously occupied our new space was Ada's Cafe. We are excited to be a new addition to this neighborhood and hope other great business will follow us here. We will miss our friends on Gladstone Street and the vision we helped create there. Our Gladstone Street store will close on August 29, 2013. Our decision to leave is solely for the purpose of ending our relationship with the landlord there. We hope the vision and change we helped establish there will continue....

New space includes Patio & Garden Center with outdoor seating & bike lock up

With our new location, we are in need of new equipment. This location includes a commercial grade hood, but it doesn't include a range or oven. We would like to make and offer a selection of natural deli foods, gluten free baked goods and create our own line of all natural kombuchas, dressings, marinates and sauces. To help other small businesses get going, we are planning to rent the kitchen as a commercial kitchen during our non-production hours. We need a range/oven, deli cooler and other kitchen equipment to make all this happen. This space has both water and electrical hookups for an espresso machine, so we need an espresso machine to offer coffee drinks.

Inside New Store

Our vision since day 1 for Stone Cottage, was to make organic smoothies and allow you the option to add nourishing ingredients like organic spirulina, organic wheat grass, organic flax seed, organic chia seeds, organic whey, local bee pollen, local raw honey, organic ginseng, organic matcha green tea, etc. We need a commercial grade smoothie blender to do so. We would like to offer fresh squeezed organic juices, but need a commercial grade juicer to do so. So that we may leave our garden starts, plant and patio furniture out overnight, we need to install a fence and gates to secure the the patio and garden center. We as well need patio furniture. Our new space has room for more shelving, products and bulk containers, which we would like to fill with new product. We also would like to add a wine selection.

New Storefront. Previously Ada's Cafe

Here is what we foresee needing in the near future: a commercial range/oven, 2 freezers, 3 refrigerators, a commercial smoothie blender, a commercial juicer, new signs for the front of the building, street and sign permits, a commercial espresso machine, stainless steel prep counters, commercial mixers, commercial food processor, pots, pans, dishes, glasses, plates, silverware, commercial coffee maker and urns, 8 shelving units, rinse sink for dishes, bulk containers, product to fill the containers, stock kitchen and displays, a deli case, ice cream case(we would like to offer the Cloud City ice cream that is made using our organic lavender), patio furniture, out door plant and produce displays, indoor produce displays, wine rack and cooler, liquor license, bakers license, non-alcoholic beverage license, food processors license.

About Stone Cottage

Our Website  2,400 Facebook Likes  1,400 Twitter Followers

When Stone opened nearly 2 years ago, it had just over 150 bulk herbs, spices, herbs, teas and culinary ingredients, most of which are organic or wild harvested. Today, they have quickly grown to become Oregon's largest selection of mostly organic or wild harvested, herbs, spices and teas, with nearly 1,000 bulk containers. They carry local bath & body products, coffee and kombucha. They have worked very hard last 2 years! They are proud and honored to be include in ZAGAT Portland City Guide and Willamette Week “Market Guide: Portland's Best Specialty Markets”, all years we have been open for business. Businesses rarely make it onto these list their first years of business. They have been credited by many, for turning a street corner (SE Cesar Chavez Blvd. & Gladstone Street) that most people previously avoided, into a gem that glows and draws you to it. They believe in support of their community and building relationships with others who share that view.

Willamette Week 2013 Market Guide

About Joshua Stephens, Store Owner. Over a dozen years ago, Joshua and his mother sold the deli and market they owned together in Brattleboro, VT. At the time, he had worked with his mother in their deli for 12 years, since age 12. Joshua traveled a few years, finally taking a train across country to settle in Southeast Portland, OR. After arriving in Portland he took a Trimet bus across town. Arriving close to his new home, he stopped in front of the very first business he went inside in his new neighborhood, Limbo. He had heard about Limbo for months and was excited to finally be in front of the well known, organic produce and specialty food store. He went inside and was in awe. With a suitcase in hand, he asked if they were hiring. They were and he started his position 2 hours later on the same day. After a few years, he became their evening manager, until Limbo closed their doors July 2011. After several years, he was jobless, when the owners of Limbo made the decision to retire. Many people were upset by the closing of Limbo because they did not know how to locate hard to find items they relied on to stay healthy. At that time Joshua made the decision with the help of his partner, family and friends, to help these people and opened the doors to Stone Cottage 2.5 months later.

Space once occupied by Limbo is now a new addition to Trader Joes
story_txt:
We are excited to announce our new location and Grand Reopening in Sellwood at 8609 SE 17th Avenue, Portland, Oregon 97202. Our projected soft open date is on or after Monday September 2, 2013, followed by our Grand Reopening and 2 Year Anniversary Celebration on September 14, 2013. This space used to be a coffee shop and restaurant, allowing us to easily incorporate new and nourishing items such as organic smoothies, fresh squeezed organic juices, natural deli products, fresh brewed organic tea, organic espresso and organic coffee. The space features a patio and garden with outdoor seating and plenty of sunshine for our garden starts and plants.

Organic Smoothies
It's conveniently located next door to a restaurant called Thia Square. We have tried their food 3 times now and it is highly recommended by us! The owner is excited to create a new organic Thai selection, using our spices, blends and produce. The days of having to fight for a parking spot or scraping your bumper as you pull into our parking lot are over. We will share with Thai Square a paved parking lot with room for 9 cars, 10 bikes and plenty of street parking around the building. Lack of decent and reasonable parking will no longer be an issue! Our new space will now include a public restroom and outdoor seating to enjoy your smoothie, coffee, tea, kombucha, pastry and/or your deli items, which will be made with all natural ingredients.

story:
My Story


I first learned about microfinance in 2006 when Dr. Mohamed Yunus won the Nobel Peace prize for developing the concepts of microfinance and microcredit. My wife and I have always given a lot to charity but when I heard about this concept I went "Wow, this is the most meaningful way to help". This is about helping people help themselves, not just cutting a cheque.


Thanks to the web based NFP called Kiva (www.kiva.org), I was able to participate by loaning money to small entrepreneurs who don’t qualify for main stream financial services.  Kiva connects borrowers and lenders through partnerships with local micro finance institutions (MFI).


I now have an opportunity to help in a more hands on way. I have been chosen to be a Kiva Fellow. KF’s are the eyes and ears on the ground for Kiva. I will be going to Indonesia and East Timor for 16 weeks to work with three Kiva partners helping them to integrate Kiva processes, verify loans and giving updates to existing Kiva lenders. I encourage you to visit www.kiva.org to find out more about it and maybe become a lender.


After my fellowship, I see myself becoming an ambassador for Kiva among my friends, in my community and beyond. It will give me credibility to spread the word about microfinance and Kiva.


Although I was selected among many applicants, this is a volunteer unpaid job. I will need to fund my own travel and living expenses. I am totally prepared to finance this opportunity myself. However, if you would like to support the work of Kiva this way you can contribute here. My total budget is $7,000 including a week of training in San Francisco. My fundraising goal is $2,000.

You might want to consider making loans through the Kiva website. It is virtually risk free. I have been loaning for over 5 years and have made 141 loans in 36 countries. My repayment rate has been 100% and Kiva's overall is 99%. All you need to do is deposit some money into a Kiva account and start loaning. When it is paid back you can reloan it or take it back. It is that easy!

story:
We're Going to Nationals!

Starting in 2013, the US Curling Association has institutued a new National Championship specifically for clubs which play on arena ice.  

Having previously won three state-level new club championships (in 2009, 2010, and a shared title in 2011), the Dakota Curling Club is excited and honored to be able to represent our region at this new National Championship.

The Arena Nationals will be played in Fort Wayne Indiana from July 18 - July 21, 2013.

What We Need 

Sending 10 humble curlers all the way to Fort Wayne for 5 days sure adds up quickly!  Many of the players are long-time club members and volunteers who contribute both to our own club's development and to curling around the region.

The total budget for both teams comes to $7500.  We have already secured a sponsorship from TGI Fridays in Burnsville (our local broomstacking location) for $700.  This campaign seeks to raise an additional $3000 to help defray expenses.  The remainder will be picked up by the players themselves.

Here's how the budget breaks out per person:

  • Travel: $150
  • 5 nights hotel (shared room): $290
  • Uniforms: $135
  • Food: $175
  • Total: $750

Even if we achieve our fund-raising goal, each player will still be contributing almost $400 out of pocket.  Funds raised in excess of our goal will be distributed equally against player's expenses.  Any funds raised over $7500 will be donated back to the Dakota Curling Club.

The Players

So who exactly are you supporting?  See below for a quick bio for each of the teams.

The Men's Team

SKIP: Paul Ellarby
Paul was one of the founders of Dakota Curling Club in 2006 and has been curling since the early 90's.

VICE: Ryan Claussen
Ryan started curling with DCC in its very first year and is currently the club President.  Ryan recently skipped a championship-winning team at an international invitational bonspiel in Inverness Scotland.

SECOND: Aaron Knewtson
Aaron has been curling with DCC since its early days and is currently the club Treasurer.

LEAD:  Dan Wennberg
Dan also joined DCC in its first year and is the club's number one volunteer.  Dan heads up our ice maintenance team and also manages our very successful corporate event program.

FIFTH: Gary Mazzota
Gary has been a long time member and supporter of DCC.  Gary played on the state championship winning team from DCC in all three years, and has competed at the Nationals level in Mixed Doubles curling.



The Women's Team

SKIP: Darcy Ellarby
Darcy was one of the founders of DCC and has been curling 12 years.  Darcy is also a Level II instructor and has helped develop the strong instructional reputation of DCC.

VICE:  Jenny Witschen
Jenny has been curling since she was a junior and has been a member of DCC since its first year of operation. Jenny is a past board member and a regular club volunteer.

SECOND: Julie Wennberg
Julie started curling with DCC in its second year and has been a long-time volunteer.  Julie is also a current board member.

LEAD: Robyn Farm
Robyn started curling in 5th grade at the age of 11 and has been playing at DCC since its inception.

FIFTH: Beth Lundquist
While a relatively new curler, Beth can claim an eight-ender in her first year of curling!  Beth is also a current board member in the capacity of Secetary.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone can help support our teams with a financial contribution. Regardless of your ability to contibute, you can still help by sharing this campaign with others.

  • Post to Facebook
  • Tweet a link to our campaign
  • Give us a pat on the back next time you run into us
  • Cheer us on!

And that’s all there is to it.  We promise to make you proud.
